<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-1-leadership-and-management-in-health-management">2.1 Leadership and Management in Health Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-1-leadership-and-management-in-health-management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Health systems cannot be strengthened without good management and leadership. Leadership and management skills are therefore essential at all levels of the health system. In addition to leadership and management skills, health managers should also embrace leadership and management practices that will lead to improved health outcomes. The key leadership and management practices are critical for the health sector are: scanning, focusing, aligning and mobilising, inspiring, planning, organising, implementing, and monitoring and evaluation.</p>
<p>Managers who lead well use all the leading and managing practices listed in Figure 2.1 below. Applying these eight practices consistently leads to strong organisational capacity, resulting in higher-quality services and sustained improvements in health.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260113-bbf3376d.jpeg" alt="img-3.jpeg">
Figure 2.1 Leading and Managing for Results Model</p>
<p>Source: Management Sciences for Health (2005).</p>
<p>The Leading and Managing for Results Model can serve as a roadmap to guide individuals, teams, and organisations to improved services and better health outcomes. By following it, health systems managers can transform discouraged, passive employees into active managers who lead.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="managing-and-leading">Managing and Leading<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#managing-and-leading" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Managing and leading are complex concepts which are relevant to many different parts of the health system, including the private and public sectors; health facilities, county and Ministry of Health directorates and support systems related to pharmaceutical, human resources for health, finances and health information. While separate concepts, managing and leading go together, each working toward a common goal but contributing in ways that the other does not. Because the two functions are complementary, the concept of "managers who lead" has gained acceptance as a holistic approach to running a health care programme, organisation or facility.</p>
<p>Managing can be defined as planning and using resources efficiently to produce intended results. Managing is focused on making sure present operations are going well. Leading is mobilising others to envision and realise a better future. While managing is focused on the present, leading is focused the future. Good health management and leadership results in measurable improvements in health services and outcomes. Heath managers' leadership and management skills therefore not only matter to their teams but also to those who benefit from their team's improved performance.</p>
<p>Leading and managing skills can be learned or improved by embracing tested practices of challenging, providing feedback and supporting your team. By so doing, you transform yourself into a manager who leads. However, learning to lead and manage takes time and</p>
<p>practice. Leading and managing comprise skills, knowledge, and attitudes that you learn through continued practice.</p>
<p>It follows from the above that health gains can be only sustained by making sure that leadership and management practices are used in all health services and supported by organisational systems and processes for managing governance, planning, human resources, finances, medicines and other health products, and information.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-2-management-and-leadership-in-the-health-care-system">2.2 Management and Leadership in the Health Care System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-2-management-and-leadership-in-the-health-care-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The key general objectives of a health care system needs are to:</p>
<ul>
<li>Improve the health status of the population (according to certain criteria and targets);</li>
<li>Deliver services in the most efficient way possible in order to accomplish the first goal.</li>
</ul>
<p>The scope and complexities of tasks carried out in pursuit of these objectives are so great that individual health workers operating on their own cannot get the work done. Moreover, the task involved in producing health services require the coordination of many specialised disciplines and support services that must work to together seamlessly. Management and leadership are therefore needed to make sure that tasks are carried out in the best way possible and that appropriate resources are adequate and well managed. Leadership and management is one of the health system building blocks as discussed in Module 1.</p>
<p>Levels of management and leadership responsibilities are:</p>
<ul>
<li>The health system and institutions therein are complex and dynamic. The nature of the system requires that management and leadership be provided at all levels as well as supervision and coordination of resources. Management and leadership are therefore essential at both the strategic and operational levels of health systems;</li>
<li>Management functions and leadership responsibilities differ at each level of the health system  Community, dispensary level, health centre level, sub-county hospital, county referral hospital, national referral hospital and at the various levels at the county and Ministry of Health headquarters;</li>
<li>They include provision and or coordination of health services, health planning, financial management, management of HRH, infrastructure management (buildings, equipment, transport, and communication), procurement, monitoring and evaluation, standards and quality assurance, leadership and governance through participation in various health management teams/boards.</li>
</ul>
<p>The aim of good management in the health sector is to provide services in an appropriate, efficient, equitable, and sustainable manner. This objective can only be achieved if key resources for service provision, including human resources, finances, infrastructure and</p>
<p>16</p>
<p>process aspects of care delivery are brought together at the point of service delivery and are carefully synchronized.</p>
<p>As in the case of any other type of institution, leadership and management play a central role in health care, especially concerning types of services provided, quality of services and resource use. As noted earlier, there is no universal recipe for successful management and leadership, contextual factors like type and level of facility, location, political leadership, and socio-economic factors play a significant part in the outcomes.</p>
<p>Whether you are in charge of a dispensary, health centre, sub-county hospital, county referral hospital, a member of the county health management team or working in one of the directorates at the Ministry of Health headquarters, your job is to improve the health of the community. Empirical evidence shows that there is a link between managing practices and leading practices and improved health outcomes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-3-management-and-leadership-practices">2.3 Management and Leadership Practices<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-3-management-and-leadership-practices" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Health systems management and leadership practices are strongly related to health outcomes. To lead and manage better, one needs to apply the eight leading and managing practices consistently. The leading and managing practices described in the Leading and Managing Framework (Figure 2.2) offer specific behaviours that can be learned and used in many different situations to improve organisational performance and sustain performance over time.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="managing-practices">Managing practices<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#managing-practices" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>When health managers use good management practices, they make sure that operational plans and reporting structures are clear and reflect organisational priorities. Because good managers reinforce the use of management systems and processes to make work easier, staff know what is expected of them, are motivated and are able to carry out their activities more effectively. Staff receive feedback on their work through supportive supervision and monitoring and evaluation systems that provide timely, reliable information.</p>
<p>The objective of good leading and managing practices is to enhance organisational:</p>
<ul>
<li>Effectiveness- the right services are offered</li>
<li>Efficiency- services delivered in the right way</li>
<li>Sustainability.</li>
</ul>
<p>To be effective, a health manager should:</p>
<ul>
<li>Plan how to achieve results by assigning resources, accountabilities, and timelines;</li>
<li>Organise people, structures, systems, and processes to carry out the plan;</li>
</ul>
<p>17</p>
<ul>
<li>Implement activities efficiently, effectively, and responsively to achieve defined results;</li>
<li>Monitor and evaluate achievements and results against plans, and continuously update information and use feedback to adjust plans, structures, systems, and processes for future results.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="leading-practices">Leading practices<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#leading-practices" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Good leadership practices are those which focus on achieving results that fulfil client needs and preferences, as well as respond to key stakeholder interests.</p>
<p>To be an effective leader, health managers should:</p>
<ul>
<li>Scan for up-to-date knowledge about yourself (to be aware how your behaviour and values affect others), your work group, your organisation, and your environment;</li>
<li>Focus staffs work on achieving organisational mission, strategy, and priorities;</li>
<li>Align and mobilise stakeholders and staffs time and energies as well as the material and financial resources to support organisational goals and priorities;</li>
<li>Inspire your staff to be committed and to continuously learn how to adapt and do things better.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="leading-and-managing-framework">Leading and managing framework<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#leading-and-managing-framework" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The Leading and Managing Framework (Figure 2.2) presents activities and organisational outcomes associated with each leading and managing practice. By applying the eight practices consistently, health managers, team leaders, supervisors, teams and organisations can systematically make improvements that will strengthen their services and improve health outcomes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="integrating-leading-and-managing-practices">Integrating leading and managing practices<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#integrating-leading-and-managing-practices" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Leading and managing occurs simultaneously. They are not distinct, sequential processes that are completed separately. The leading practices are not independent of the managing practices. They complement and support each other. Effective managers move fluidly between leading and managing to support their teams to face challenges and achieve results.</p>
<p>Facing challenges involves scanning, focusing and planning as shown in Figure 2.3. The process of scanning the environment to identify challenges is followed by a deliberate effort to focus on a few priority challenges and making a plan to address them. Planning is followed by building stakeholder support, mobilising resources and implementing the plan.</p>
<p>18</p>
<p>Figure 2.2 Leading and Managing Framework</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Leading</th><th>Managing</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>scanning identify client and stakeholder needs and priorities recognize trends, opportunities, and risks that affect the organization look for best practices identify staff capacities and constraints know yourself, your staff, and your organization  values, strengths, and weaknesses ORGANIZATIONAL OUTCOME Managers have up-to-date, valid knowledge of their clients, the organization, and its context; they know how their behavior affects others</td><td>planning set short-term organizational goals and performance objectives develop multi-year and annual plans allocate adequate resources (money, people, and materials) anticipate and reduce risks ORGANIZATIONAL OUTCOME Organization has defined results, assigned resources, and an operational plan</td></tr><tr><td>focusing articulate the organization's mission and strategy identify critical challenges link goals with the overall organizational strategy determine key priorities for action create a common picture of desired results ORGANIZATIONAL OUTCOME Organization's work is directed by well-defined mission, strategy, and priorities</td><td>organizing ensure a structure that provides accountability and delineates authority ensure that systems for human resource management, finance, logistics, quality assurance, operations, information, and marketing effectively support the plan strengthen work processes to implement the plan align staff capacities with planned activities ORGANIZATIONAL OUTCOME Organization has functional structures, systems, and processes for efficient operations; staff are organized and aware of job responsibilities and expectations</td></tr><tr><td>aligning/mobilizing ensure congruence of values, mission, strategy, structure, systems, and daily actions facilitate teamwork unite key stakeholders around an inspiring vision link goals with rewards and recognition enlist stakeholders to commit resources ORGANIZATIONAL OUTCOME Internal and external stakeholders understand and support the organization' goals and have mobilized resources to reach these goals</td><td>implementing integrate systems and coordinate work flow balance competing demands routinely use data for decision-making coordinate activities with other programs and sectors adjust plans and resources as circumstances change ORGANIZATIONAL OUTCOME Activities are carried out efficiently, effectively, and responsively</td></tr><tr><td>inspiring match deeds to words demonstrate honesty in interactions show trust and confidence in staff, acknowledge the contributions of others provide staff with challenges, feedback, and support be a model of creativity, innovation, and learning ORGANIZATIONAL OUTCOME Organization displays a climate of continuous learning and staff show commitment, even when setbacks occur</td><td>monitoring and evaluating monitor and reflect on progress against plans provide feedback identify needed changes improve work processes, procedures, and tools ORGANIZATIONAL OUTCOME Organization continuously updates information about the status of achievements and results, and applies ongoing learning and knowledge</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Source: Management Sciences for Health (2005).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260113-bf3d3846.jpeg" alt="img-4.jpeg">
Figure 2.3 Integrated Leading and Managing Process</p>
<p>Source: Management Sciences for Health (2005).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="leadership-competencies">Leadership competencies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#leadership-competencies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Leadership competencies are the specific mindset, skills, and knowledge that help managers lead more effectively. In addition to having the right mindset one needs knowledge and skills in order to be able to empower others to achieve results.</p>
<p>Table 2.1 Leadership Competencies</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Competency</th><th>Application</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Master yourself</td><td>Reflect on yourself and be aware of your impact on others, manage your emotions effectively, use your strengths, and work on your shortcomings</td></tr><tr><td>See the big picture</td><td>Look beyond a narrow focus to take into account conditions outside your immediate area of work</td></tr><tr><td>Create a shared vision</td><td>Work with others to envision a better future and use this vision to focus all your efforts</td></tr><tr><td>Clarify purpose and priorities</td><td>Know your own values and what is most important to accomplish</td></tr><tr><td>Communicate effectively</td><td>Hold conversations focused on outcomes; balance advocacy with inquiry; and clarify assumptions, beliefs, and feelings within yourself and others</td></tr><tr><td>Motivate committed teams</td><td>Create the clarity, trust, and recognition necessary to lead teams to high performance that can be sustained over time</td></tr><tr><td>Negotiate conflict</td><td>Reach agreements from which both sides can benefit</td></tr><tr><td>Lead change</td><td>Enable your work group to own challenges, enlist stakeholders, and navigate through unstable conditions</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Source: Management Sciences for Health (2005).</p>
<p>Table 2.2 Comparisons of Management and Leadership Competencies</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Management Produces</th><th>Leadership Produces</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td> Planning and budgeting  Establishing agendas  Setting timetables  Allocating resources</td><td> Establishing direction  Creating a vision  Clarifying the big picture  Setting strategies</td></tr><tr><td> Organizing and staffing  Provide structure  Making job placements  Establishing rules and procedures</td><td> Aligning people  Communicating goals  Seeking commitment  Building teams and coalitions</td></tr><tr><td> Controlling and problem solving  Developing incentives  Generating creative solutions  Taking corrective action</td><td> Motivating and inspiring  Inspiring and energize  Empowering subordinates  Satisfying unmet needs</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Source: Kotter (1990).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="2-4-team-management-in-health-care-settings">2.4 Team Management in Health Care Settings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-4-team-management-in-health-care-settings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Provision of health care and health care management and leadership takes place in a group or team setting. A team is a group of people who work together cooperatively to achieve a common goal. The literature on teams underscores that a team's structure differs depending upon its purpose, task, setting, the mix of professions on the team, and the formal relationships between health professionals in the team.</p>
<p>A team may be defined as a collection of individuals who are interdependent in their tasks, who share responsibility for outcomes, who see themselves and who are seen by others as an intact social entity embedded in one or more larger social systems and who manage their relationships across organisational borders (Hackman, 1978).</p>
<p>The best and most cost-effective outcomes for patients and clients are achieved when professionals work together, learn together, engage in clinical audit of outcomes together, and generate innovation to ensure progress in practice and service.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="types-of-medical-teams">Types of Medical Teams<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-medical-teams" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There are many types of teams in health care. They include labour and delivery units, ICUs, medical wards, primary care teams in the community, teams assembled for a specific task such as an emergency response team or multi-professional teams such as multidisciplinary cancer care teams that come together to plan and coordinate a patient's care. Teams can include a single discipline or involve the input from multiple practitioner types including</p>
<p>doctors, nurses, pharmacists, physiotherapists, social workers, psychologists and potentially administrative staff.</p>
<p>The role played by each of these practitioners varies between teams and within teams at different times. Roles of individuals in the team are often flexible and opportunistic such as the leadership changing depending on the required expertise or the nurse taking on the patient education role given they have regular contact with patients.</p>
<p>i. Core Teams</p>
<p>Core teams consist of team leaders and members who are involved in the direct care of the patient. Core team members include direct care providers (from the home base of operation for each unit) and continuity providers (those who manage the patient from assessment to disposition, for example, case managers). The core team, such as a unit-based team (physician, nurses, physiotherapist, and pharmacist) is generally based where the patient receives care.</p>
<p>ii. Coordinating Teams</p>
<p>A coordinating team is the group responsible for:</p>
<ul>
<li>Day-to-day operational management;</li>
<li>Coordination functions;</li>
<li>Resource management for core teams.</li>
</ul>
<p>iii. Contingency Teams</p>
<p>Contingency teams are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Formed for emergent or specific events;</li>
<li>Time-limited events (e.g. cardiac arrest teams, disaster response teams, rapid response teams);</li>
<li>Composed of team members drawn from a variety of core teams.</li>
</ul>
<p>iv. Ancillary Services</p>
<p>Ancillary services consist of individuals such as catering, cleaners and other support staff who:</p>
<ul>
<li>Provide direct, task-specific, time-limited care to patients;</li>
<li>Support services that facilitate care of patients;</li>
<li>Are often not located where patients receive routine care.</li>
</ul>
<p>22</p>
<p>Ancillary services are primarily a service delivery team whose mission is to support the core team. This does not mean that they should not share the same goals. The successful outcome of a patient undergoing surgery requires accurate information on catering and instructions in relation to "nil by mouth" orders so that a patient does not inadvertently receive a meal that may place them at risk of choking. In general, an ancillary services team functions independently. However, there may be times when they should be considered as part of the core team.</p>
<p>v. Support Sservices</p>
<p>Support services consist of individuals who:</p>
<ul>
<li>Provide indirect, task-specific services in a health-care facility;</li>
<li>Are service-focused, integral members of the team, helping to facilitate the optimal health care experience for patients and their families.</li>
</ul>
<p>Support services consist primarily of a service focused team whose mission is to create efficient, safe, comfortable and clean health-care environments, which impact the patient care team, market perception, operational efficiency and patient safety.</p>
<p>vi. Administration</p>
<p>Administration includes the executive leadership of a unit or facility, and has 24-hour accountability for the overall function and management of the organisation. Administration shapes the climate and culture for a teamwork system to flourish by:</p>
<ul>
<li>Establishing and communicating vision;</li>
<li>Developing and enforcing policies;</li>
<li>Setting expectations for staff;</li>
<li>Providing necessary resources for successful implementation;</li>
<li>Holding teams accountable for team performance;</li>
<li>Defining the culture of the organisation.</li>
</ul>
<p>The Challenge Model</p>
<p>Leading means helping people identify and face challenges. Taking on a challenge requires that all members are committed to working together as a team. The Challenge Model enables people to move from vision to action. It helps in making a careful diagnosis of where you want to go and where you currently are before you decide on a plan of action. The Challenge Model (Figure 2.4) offers a systematic approach for working together, as a team, to identify and face one challenge at a time and achieve results. The model leads the user through a</p>
<p>23</p>
<p>process of forming commitment to a shared vision that contributes to realising their organisation's mission, defining and owning a challenge, prioritising actions for implementation, and carrying out the work plan to achieve results. The model can be used to address all kinds of management and leadership challenges.</p>
<p>Figure 2.4 The Challenge Model
<img src="assets/images/image-20260113-1a94b9f0.jpeg" alt="img-5.jpeg">
Source: Management Sciences for Health (2005).</p>
<p>How to . . .</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="use-the-challenge-model">Use the Challenge Model<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#use-the-challenge-model" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-1-review-your-organizational-mission-and-strategic-priorities">Step 1. Review your organizational mission and strategic priorities<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-1-review-your-organizational-mission-and-strategic-priorities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>With your team, form a common understanding of your organization's mission and strategic priorities. This understanding will help you shape your vision and make sure that it contributes to the larger organizational priorities.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-2-create-a-shared-vision">Step 2. Create a shared vision<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-2-create-a-shared-vision" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Work with your team to create a shared vision of the future you want and that contributes to accomplishing the organization's mission and priorities. This shared vision serves to inspire the team to face each new challenge.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-3-agree-on-one-measurable-result">Step 3. Agree on one measurable result<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-3-agree-on-one-measurable-result" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pick an aspect of your shared vision and create one measurable result that you all want to achieve. This measurable result is what will drive your work. Because it is measurable, it allows you to monitor and evaluate your progress toward achieving it.</p>
<p>Note that <em>finalizing</em> the result is an iterative process. As you learn more about the current situation and obstacles you need to overcome, you may need to adjust your stated result so that it is appropriate and realistic.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-4-assess-the-current-situation">Step 4. Assess the current situation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-4-assess-the-current-situation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Scan your internal and external environments to form an accurate baseline of the realities or conditions that describe the current situation in relation to your stated result.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-5-identify-the-obstacles-and-their-root-causes">Step 5. Identify the obstacles and their root causes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-5-identify-the-obstacles-and-their-root-causes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Make a list of obstacles that you and your team will have to overcome to reach your stated result. Use root cause analysis tools to analyze the underlying causes of these obstacles to make sure you are addressing the causes and not just the symptoms.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-6-define-your-key-challenge-and-select-priority-actions">Step 6. Define your key challenge and select priority actions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-6-define-your-key-challenge-and-select-priority-actions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>State what you plan to achieve in light of the root causes of the obstacles you have identified. (It helps to begin your challenge statement with "How will we...?") Then select priority actions that you will implement to address the root causes of the obstacles.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-7-develop-an-action-plan">Step 7. Develop an action plan<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-7-develop-an-action-plan" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Develop an action plan that estimates the human, material, and financial resources needed and the timeline for implementing your actions.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="step-8-implement-your-plan-and-monitor-and-evaluate-your-progress">Step 8. Implement your plan and monitor and evaluate your progress<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#step-8-implement-your-plan-and-monitor-and-evaluate-your-progress" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Provide support to your team in implementing the plan, and monitor and evaluate your progress toward achieving your result.</p>
<p>25</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="characteristics-of-an-effective-team">Characteristics of an Effective Team<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characteristics-of-an-effective-team" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There are many models describing effective teamwork. Mickan and Roger (2005) offer the following six simple characteristics, presented in Table 2.3 below, that underpin effective health-care teams:</p>
<p>Table 2.3 Characteristics of an Effective Team</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Common purpose</th><th>Team members generate a common and clearly defined purpose that includes collective interests and demonstrates shared ownership.</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Measurable goals</td><td>Teams set goals that are measurable and focused on the team's task.</td></tr><tr><td>Effective leadership</td><td>Teams require effective leadership that set and maintain structures, manage conflict, listen to members and trust and support members. It is important for teams to agree and share leadership functions.</td></tr><tr><td>Effective communication</td><td>Good teams share ideas and information quickly and regularly, keep written records as well as allow time for team reflection. Some of the most in-depth analysis of inter-professional team communication has occurred in high stakes teams such as are found in surgery.</td></tr><tr><td>Good cohesion</td><td>Cohesive teams have a unique and identifiable team spirit and commitment and have greater longevity as teams members want to continue working together.</td></tr><tr><td>Mutual respect</td><td>Effective teams have members who respect the talents and beliefs of each person in addition to their professional contributions. In addition, effective teams accept and encourage a diversity of opinion among members.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>A health care system that supports effective teamwork can improve the quality of patient care, enhance patient safety, and reduce workload issues that cause burnout among health care professionals. Teams work most effectively when they have a clear purpose; good communication; co-ordination; protocols and procedures and effective mechanisms to resolve conflict when it arises. The active participation of all members is another key feature. Successful teams recognise the professional and personal contributions of all members; promote individual development and team interdependence; recognize the benefits of working together; and see accountability as a collective responsibility. The make-up and functioning of teams varies depending on the needs of the patient. The complexity of the health issue defines the task. The more interdependency needed to serve the patient, the greater the need for collaboration among team members.</p>
<p>Patients and their families are important team members with an important role in decision-making. To enable patients to participate effectively, they need to learn and be told how to participate in the team; how to obtain information about their condition; and how each health</p>
<p>care professional will contribute to their care. Teams function differently depending on where they operate. Teams in hospitals have clearly defined protocols and procedures, professional hierarchies, and shared institutional goals, while teams in community-based primary care practices operate within the community setting.</p>
<p>Teamwork is influenced by organisational culture. A clear organisational philosophy on the importance of teamwork can promote collaboration by encouraging new ways of working together; the development of common goals; and mechanisms to overcome resistance to change and turf wars amongst health workers about scopes of practice. Teams need training to learn how to work together and understand the professional role/responsibility of each member. They also require an effective administrative structure and leadership.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="collaboration">Collaboration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#collaboration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Effective teams are characterised by trust, respect, and collaboration. Collaboration in health care is defined as health care professionals assuming complementary roles and cooperatively working together, sharing responsibility for problem-solving and making decisions to formulate and carry out plans for patient care. Collaboration between physicians, nurses, and other health care professionals increases team members' awareness of each others' type of knowledge and skills, leading to continued improvement in decision making (O'Daniel and Rosenstein, 2008).</p>
<p>When considering a teamwork model in health care, an interdisciplinary approach should be applied. Unlike a multidisciplinary approach, in which each team member is responsible only for the activities related to his or her own discipline and formulates separate goals for the patient, an interdisciplinary approach coalesces a joint effort on behalf of the patient with a common goal from all disciplines involved in the care plan. The pooling of specialised services leads to integrated interventions. The plan of care takes into account the multiple assessments and treatment regimens, and it packages these services to create an individualised care programme that best addresses the needs of the patient.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="components-of-successful-teamwork">Components of Successful Teamwork<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#components-of-successful-teamwork" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Open communication</li>
<li>Non-punitive environment</li>
<li>Clear direction;</li>
<li>Clear and known roles and tasks for team members</li>
<li>Respectful atmosphere</li>
<li>Shared responsibility for team success</li>
<li>Appropriate balance of member participation for the task at hand</li>
</ul>
<p>27</p>
<ul>
<li>Acknowledgment and processing of conflict</li>
<li>Clear specifications regarding authority and accountability</li>
<li>Clear and known decision making procedures</li>
<li>Regular and routine communication and information sharing</li>
<li>Enabling environment, including access to needed resources</li>
<li>Mechanism to evaluate outcomes and adjust accordingly</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="common-barriers-to-inter-professional-collaboration">Common Barriers to Inter-Professional Collaboration<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#common-barriers-to-inter-professional-collaboration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Personal values and expectations</li>
<li>Personality differences</li>
<li>Hierarchy</li>
<li>Disruptive behaviour</li>
<li>Culture and ethnicity</li>
<li>Generational differences</li>
<li>Gender;</li>
<li>Historical inter-professional and intra-professional rivalries</li>
<li>Differences in language and jargon</li>
<li>Differences in schedules and professional routines</li>
<li>Varying levels of preparation, qualifications, and status</li>
<li>Differences in requirements, regulations, and norms of professional education</li>
<li>Fears of diluted professional identity</li>
<li>Differences in accountability, remuneration, and rewards</li>
<li>Concerns regarding clinical responsibility</li>
<li>Complexity of care</li>
<li>Emphasis on rapid decision making</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="stages-of-team-development">Stages of Team Development<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stages-of-team-development" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Team formation takes time, and usually follows some easily recognisable stages, as the team journeys from being a group of strangers to becoming a united team with a common goal.</p>
<p>28</p>
<p>According to leading experts in group dynamics, teams go through predictable phases. Psychologist Bruce Tuckman first came up with the memorable phrase forming, storming, norming, and performing back in 1965. He used it to describe the path to high-performance that most teams follow. In 1975, he added a fifth stage he called adjourning.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="stage-1-forming">Stage 1: Forming<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stage-1-forming" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In the Forming stage, personal relations are characterised by dependence. Group members rely on safe, patterned behaviour and look to the group leader for guidance and direction. Group members have a desire for acceptance by the group and a need to know that the group is safe. They set about gathering impressions and data about the similarities and differences among them and forming preferences for future sub grouping. Rules of behaviour seem to be to keep things simple and to avoid controversy. Serious topics and feelings are avoided.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="stage-2-storming">Stage 2: Storming<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stage-2-storming" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The Storming stage is characterised by competition and conflict in the personal relations within the group. As the group members attempt to organise for the task, conflict inevitably results in their personal relations. Individuals have to bend and mold their feelings, ideas, attitudes, and beliefs to suit the group organisation. Because of fear of exposure or fear of failure, there is an increased desire for structural clarification and commitment. Although conflicts may or may not surface as group issues, they do exist. Questions will arise about who is going to be responsible for what, what the rules are, what the reward system is, and what the criteria for evaluation are. These reflect conflicts over leadership, structure, power, and authority. There may be wide swings in members behaviour based on emerging issues of competition and hostilities. Because of the discomfort generated during this stage, some members may remain completely silent while others attempt to dominate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="stage-3-norming">Stage 3: Norming<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stage-3-norming" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In the Norming stage, interpersonal relations are characterised by cohesion. Group members are engaged in active acknowledgment of all members contributions, group building and maintenance, and solving of group issues. Members are willing to change their preconceived ideas or opinions on the basis of facts presented by other members, and they actively ask questions of one another. Leadership is shared, and cliques dissolve. When members begin to know and identify with one another, the level of trust in their personal relations contributes to the development of group cohesion. It is during this stage of development (assuming the group gets this far) that people begin to experience a sense of group belonging and a feeling of relief as a result of resolving interpersonal conflicts.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="stage-4-performing">Stage 4: Performing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stage-4-performing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The Performing stage is not reached by all groups. If group members get to stage four, their capacity, range, and depth of personal relations expand to true interdependence. In this stage,</p>
<p>29</p>
<p>people can work independently, in subgroups, or as a total unit with equal facility. Their roles and authorities dynamically adjust to the changing needs of the group and individuals.</p>
<p>Stage four is marked by interdependence in personal relations and problem solving in the realm of task functions. At this stage, the group should be most productive. Individual members become self-assuring, and the need for group approval is past. Members are both highly task-oriented and people-oriented. There is unity: group identity is complete, group morale is high, and group loyalty is intense. The task function becomes genuine problem solving, leading towards optimal solutions and group development. There is support for experimentation in problem-solving and emphasis on achievement. The overall goal is productivity through problem-solving and work.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="stage-5-adjourning">Stage 5: Adjourning<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stage-5-adjourning" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The final stage, Adjourning, involves break-up of the group, hopefully when the task is completed successfully and its purpose fulfilled. Everyone can move on to new things, feeling good about what has been achieved. From an organisational perspective, recognition of, and sensitivity to people's vulnerabilities is essential, especially if members have closely bonded and feel a sense of insecurity or threat from this change</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="team-development-process">Team Development Process<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#team-development-process" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Figure 2.5 Team Development Process
<img src="assets/images/image-20260113-d1e616af.jpeg" alt="img-6.jpeg">
Source: Tuckman (1965).</p>
<p>Table 2.4 Leadership Activities at Different Group Formation Stages</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Stage</th><th>Activity</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Forming</td><td>Direct the team and establish objectives clearly. A good way of doing this is to negotiate a team charter. Team Charters are documents that define the purpose of the team, how it will work, and what the expected outcomes are. They are roadmaps that the team and its sponsors create at the beginning of the journey to make sure that all involved are clear about where they're heading, and to give direction when times get tough.</td></tr><tr><td>Storming</td><td>Establish process and structure, and work to smooth conflict and build good relationships between team members. Generally provide support, especially to those team members who are less secure. Remain positive and firm in the face of challenges to your leadership or the teams goal. Perhaps explain the forming, storming, norming and performing idea so that people understand why conflict is occurring, and understand that things will get better in the future. And consider teaching assertiveness and conflict resolution skills where these are necessary.</td></tr><tr><td>Norming</td><td>Step back and help the team take responsibility for progress towards the goal. This is a good time to arrange a social, or a team-building event.</td></tr><tr><td>Performing</td><td>Delegate as far as you sensibly can. Once the team has achieved high performance, you should aim to have as light a touch as possible. You will now be able to start focusing on other goals and areas of work.</td></tr><tr><td>Adjourning</td><td>When breaking up a team, take the time to celebrate its achievements. After all, you may well work with some of your people again, and this will be much easier if people view past experiences positively.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="barriers-to-effective-teamwork">Barriers to Effective Teamwork<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#barriers-to-effective-teamwork" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A number of specific barriers exist to establishing and maintaining effective teamwork in health care. These include:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i-changing-roles">i. Changing roles<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-changing-roles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There are currently considerable change and overlap in the roles played by different healthcare professionals. Examples include radiographers reading plain film X-rays, nurses performing colonoscopies and nurse practitioners having prescribing rights. These changing roles can present challenges to teams in terms of role allocation and acknowledgement.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ii-changing-settings">ii. Changing settings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-changing-settings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The nature of health care is changing including increased delivery of care for chronic conditions into community care and many surgical procedures to day-care centres. These changes require the development of new teams and the modification of existing ones.</p>
<p>iii. Medical hierarchies</p>
<p>Medicine is strongly hierarchical in nature and this is counterproductive in terms of establishing and effectively running teams where all members' views are accepted and the team leader is not always a doctor. While there has been a growing acknowledgement that teamwork is important in health care, this has not necessarily been translated into change practices, especially in environments where cultural norms of communication may mitigate against teamwork.</p>
<p>iv. Individualistic nature of medicine</p>
<p>The practice of medicine is based on the autonomous one-on-one relation between the doctor and patient. While this relationship remains a core value, it is challenged by many concepts of teamwork and shared care. This can be at many levels including doctors being unwilling to share the care of their patients through to medico-legal implications of team-based care.</p>
<p>v. Instability of teams</p>
<p>As already indicated, health-care teams are often transitory in nature, coming together for a specific task or event (such as cardiac arrest teams). The transitory nature of these teams places great emphasis on the quality of training for team members, which raises particular challenges in medicine where education and training is often relegated at the expense of service delivery.</p>
<p>2.5 Managing Conflict within Health Teams</p>
<p>We experience conflict in our everyday lives and probably have many feelings about it. Conflict situations are an important aspect of the workplace. Webster's Ninth New Collegiate Dictionary defines conflict as a fight, battle, war meaning:</p>
<p>i. Competitive or opposing action of incompatibles: antagonistic state or action (as of divergent ideas, interests, or persons).</p>
<p>ii. Mental struggle resulting from incompatible or opposing needs, drives, wishes, or external or internal demands.</p>
<p>The opposition of persons or forces that gives rise to the dramatic action in a drama or fiction. This definition expresses what people usually mean by 'conflict'. As implied in the second part of the dictionary definition, conflict is not bad. Conflict involves: competing or opposing forces. The conflict may be about ideas, interests, or just differences between people. Conflict is therefore an outgrowth of diversity (Dudley, 1994).</p>
<p>Types and Sources of Conflict</p>
<p>Conflict can be classified as constructive or destructive. Constructive (functional) conflict helps a group achieve its objectives. Destructive (dysfunctional) conflict hinders achievement</p>
<p>32</p>
<p>of objectives. A manager's job is to eliminate destructive conflict or change it into constructive conflict.</p>
<p>Conflict may also be classified in terms of the people involved:</p>
<ol>
<li>Individual conflict when faced with contradictory priorities;</li>
<li>Interpersonal conflict between two people;</li>
<li>Conflict between an individual and a group when the individual breaks the group's norms;</li>
<li>Conflict between groups or departments;</li>
<li>Conflict between stakeholders in a health system.</li>
</ol>
<p>Table 2.5 Causes of Conflict in Organisations</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Personal differences</th><th>These often arise from different needs, beliefs, values, perceptions, and expectations.</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Information</td><td>Arises from the use of different sources of information or different interpretations of the same information.</td></tr><tr><td>Different objectives</td><td>Individuals and groups can have different or incompatible objectives.</td></tr><tr><td>Environmental factors</td><td>Arises from competition for organisational resources.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Source: Spaho (2013).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="conflict-management-techniques">Conflict Management Techniques<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#conflict-management-techniques" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A conflict is a situation when the interests, needs, goals or values of involved parties interfere with one another. A conflict is a common phenomenon in the workplace. Different stakeholders may have different priorities; conflicts may involve team members, departments, projects, organisation and client, boss and subordinate, organisation needs vs. personal needs. Often, a conflict is a result of perception. Conflict is not necessarily a bad thing. In a workplace situation, it can present opportunities for improvement. Therefore, it is important to understand (and apply) various conflict resolution techniques.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-forcing">i. Forcing<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-forcing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Also known as competing. An individual firmly pursues his or her own concerns despite the resistance of the other person or party. A user of the forcing conflict style attempts to resolve</p>
<p>the conflict by getting his or her way. It is an assertive, uncooperative, autocratic style that attempts to satisfy one's needs at the expense of those of others. It creates a win-lose situation.</p>
<p>Examples of when forcing may be appropriate include are:</p>
<ul>
<li>In certain situations when all other, less forceful methods, do not work or are ineffective;</li>
<li>When you need to stand up for your own rights, resist aggression and pressure;</li>
<li>When a quick resolution is required and using force is justified (e.g. in a life-threatening situation, to stop an aggression);</li>
<li>As a last resort to resolve a long-lasting conflict.</li>
</ul>
<p>Possible advantages of forcing are:</p>
<ul>
<li>May provide a quick resolution to a conflict;</li>
<li>Increases self-esteem and draws respect when firm resistance or actions were a response to an aggression or hostility.</li>
</ul>
<p>Some caveats of forcing include:</p>
<ul>
<li>May negatively affect your relationship with the opponent in the long-run;</li>
<li>May cause the opponent to react in the same way, even if the opponent did not intend to be forceful originally;</li>
<li>Cannot take advantage of the strong sides of the other sides position;</li>
<li>Taking this approach may require a lot of energy and be exhausting to some individuals.</li>
</ul>
<p>ii. Win-win (Collaborating)</p>
<p>Also known as problem-confronting or problem-solving. Collaboration involves an attempt to work with the other person to find a win-win solution to the problem in hand  the one that most satisfies the concerns of both parties. The win-win approach sees conflict resolution as an opportunity to come to a mutually beneficial result. It includes identifying underlying concerns of the opponents and finding an alternative which meets each party's concerns. Examples of when collaborating may be appropriate are:</p>
<ul>
<li>When consensus and commitment of other parties is important;</li>
<li>In a collaborative environment;</li>
<li>When it is required to address the interests of multiple stakeholders;</li>
</ul>
<p>34</p>
<ul>
<li>When a high level of trust is present;</li>
<li>When a long-term relationship is important;</li>
<li>When you need to work through hard feelings, animosity, etc.;</li>
<li>When you do not want to take full responsibility.</li>
</ul>
<p>Possible advantages of collaborating are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Leads to solving the actual problem;</li>
<li>Leads to a win-win outcome;</li>
<li>Reinforces mutual trust and respect;</li>
<li>Builds a foundation for effective collaboration in the future;</li>
<li>Shared responsibility of the outcome;</li>
<li>You earn the reputation of a good negotiator;</li>
<li>For parties involved, the outcome of the conflict resolution is less stressful. However, the process of finding and establishing a win-win solution may be very involved.</li>
</ul>
<p>Some caveats of collaborating include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Requires a commitment from all parties to look for a mutually acceptable solution;</li>
<li>May require more effort and more time than some other methods. A win-win solution may not be evident;</li>
<li>For the same reason, collaborating may not be practical when timing is crucial and a quick solution or fast response is required;</li>
<li>Once one or more parties lose their trust in an opponent, the relationship falls back to other methods of conflict resolution. Therefore, all involved parties must continue collaborative efforts to maintain a collaborative relationship.</li>
</ul>
<p>iii. Compromising</p>
<p>Compromising looks for an expedient and mutually acceptable solution which partially satisfies both parties. This style is an attempt to resolve conflict through give and take and by making concessions. It involves both assertiveness and cooperation and attempts to meet a person's needs for harmonious relationships. A win-lose or lose-lose situation may result.</p>
<p>Examples of when compromise may be appropriate are:</p>
<ul>
<li>When the goals are moderately important and not worth the use of more assertive or more involving approaches, such as forcing or collaborating;</li>
</ul>
<p>35</p>
<ul>
<li>To reach temporary settlement on complex issues;</li>
<li>To reach expedient solutions on important issues;</li>
<li>As a first step when the involved parties do not know each other well or have not yet developed a high level of mutual trust;</li>
<li>When collaboration or forcing do not work.</li>
</ul>
<p>Possible advantages of compromise are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Faster issue resolution. Compromising may be more practical when time is a factor;</li>
<li>Can provide a temporary solution while still looking for a win-win solution;</li>
<li>Lowers the levels of tension and stress resulting from the conflict.</li>
</ul>
<p>Some caveats of using compromise include:</p>
<ul>
<li>May result in a situation when both parties are not satisfied with the outcome (a lose-lose situation);</li>
<li>Does not contribute to building trust in the long-run;</li>
<li>May require close monitoring and control to ensure the agreements are met.</li>
</ul>
<p>iv. Withdrawing</p>
<p>This is also known as avoiding. This is when a person does not pursue her/his own concerns or those of the opponent. He/she does not address the conflict, sidesteps, postpones or simply withdraws. Someone using this style attempts to ignore conflict rather than resolve it. It is unassertive and uncooperative and represents an attempt to satisfy needs by avoiding or postponing confrontation. A lose-lose situation is created. Examples of when withdrawing may be appropriate include:</p>
<ul>
<li>When the issue is trivial and not worth the effort;</li>
<li>When more important issues are pressing and you do not have time to deal with it;</li>
<li>In situations where postponing the response is beneficial to you;</li>
<li>When it is not the right time or place to confront the issue;</li>
<li>When you need time to think and collect information before you act e.g. if you are unprepared or taken by surprise;</li>
<li>When you see no chance of getting your concerns met or you would have to put forth unreasonable efforts;</li>
<li>When you would have to deal with hostility;</li>
</ul>
<p>36</p>
<ul>
<li>When you are unable to handle the conflict e.g. if you are too emotionally involved or others can handle it better.</li>
</ul>
<p>Possible advantages of withdrawing are:</p>
<ul>
<li>When the opponent is forcing/attempts aggression, you may choose to withdraw and postpone your response until you are in a more favourable circumstance for you to push back;</li>
<li>Withdrawing is a low stress approach when the conflict is short;</li>
<li>Gives the ability/time to focus on more important or more urgent issues instead;</li>
<li>Gives you time to better prepare and collect information before you act.</li>
</ul>
<p>Some caveats of withdrawing include:</p>
<ul>
<li>May lead to weakening or losing your position; not acting may be interpreted as an agreement. Using withdrawing strategies without negatively affecting your own position requires certain skill and experience;</li>
<li>When multiple parties are involved, withdrawing may negatively affect your relationship with a party that expects your action.</li>
</ul>
<p>v. Smoothing</p>
<p>This is also known as accommodating. Smoothing is accommodating the concerns of other people first of all, rather than one's own concerns. Someone using this style resolves the conflict by giving in to the other party. It is unassertive and cooperative and attempts to satisfy the other party while neglecting his or her own needs. A win-lose situation is created with the other party winning. Examples of when smoothing may be appropriate are:</p>
<ul>
<li>When it is important to provide a temporary relief from the conflict or buy time until you are in a better position to respond/push back;</li>
<li>When the issue is not as important to you as it is to the other person;</li>
<li>When you accept that you are wrong;</li>
<li>When you have no choice or when continued competition would be detrimental.</li>
</ul>
<p>Possible advantages of smoothing are:</p>
<ul>
<li>In some cases smoothing will help to protect more important interests while giving up on some less important ones;</li>
<li>Gives an opportunity to reassess the situation from a different angle.</li>
</ul>
<p>Some caveats of smoothing include:</p>
<p>37</p>
<ul>
<li>There is a risk to be abused, i.e. the opponent may constantly try to take advantage of your tendency toward smoothing/accommodating. Therefore it is important to keep the right balance and this requires some skill;</li>
<li>May negatively affect your confidence in your ability to respond to an aggressive opponent;</li>
<li>It makes it more difficult to transition to a win-win solution in the future;</li>
<li>Some of your supporters may not like your smoothing response.</li>
</ul>
