<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-1-quality-management-principles-and-concepts">7.1 Quality Management Principles and Concepts<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-1-quality-management-principles-and-concepts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="quality-management">Quality Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#quality-management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Quality management focuses on the means and processes of ensuring that the products or services offered in a health facility are consistent and are also referred to as Total Quality Management (TQM).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="quality-management-principles">Quality Management Principles<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#quality-management-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The key principles of quality management are: Customer focus; leadership; involvement of people; process approach; systems thinking; continuous improvement; informed decision making and establishment of mutually beneficial relationships. These principles are described further below:</p>
<p>116</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="principle-1-customer-focus">Principle 1: Customer focus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principle-1-customer-focus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A customer focus approach to quality management seeks to ensure that the objectives of the health facility or organisations are linked to customer (patients) needs and expectations at all times. Measures to sustain customer focus include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Researching and understanding customer needs and expectations;</li>
<li>Communicating customer needs and expectations throughout the organisation;</li>
<li>Measuring customer satisfaction and acting on the results of the measurement;</li>
<li>Systematically managing customer relationships;</li>
<li>Ensuring a balanced approach between satisfying customers and other interested parties such as MOH, employees, suppliers, financiers, local communities and society as a whole.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="principle-2-leadership-in-quality-management">Principle 2: Leadership in quality management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principle-2-leadership-in-quality-management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Leadership in quality management involves considering the needs of all interested parties including customers, owners, employees, suppliers, financiers, local communities and society as a whole. Below are several aspects of leadership that can be considered:</p>
<ul>
<li>Establishing a clear vision of the organisations future;</li>
<li>Setting challenging goals and targets for the institution;</li>
<li>Creating and sustaining shared values, fairness and ethical role models at all levels of the organisation;</li>
<li>Establishing trust and eliminating fear within the institution;</li>
<li>Providing people with the required resources, training and freedom to act with responsibility and accountability;</li>
<li>Inspiring, encouraging and recognising peoples contributions.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="principle-3-involvement">Principle 3: Involvement<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principle-3-involvement" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This principle involves motivating the staff at all levels and promotion of and recognition of creativity and innovativeness. This ensures that staff members feel involved and hence makes the process easier to implement and make part of daily tasks.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="principle-4-process-approach">Principle 4: Process approach<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principle-4-process-approach" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Process approach in quality management involves paying attention to the processes that are supposed to produce the intended result(s). It means looking at how things are done, and how inputs are turned into outputs. Examples of resource inputs/outputs include staff,</p>
<p>finances and supplies. Services inputs/outputs may include decisions, authorisations, feedback comments, solutions and proposals among others.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="principle-5-system-approach-to-management">Principle 5: System approach to management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principle-5-system-approach-to-management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Systems approach to management also referred to as systems thinking. It involves identifying, understanding and managing interrelated processes as a system. System thinking ensures that a manager acknowledges that an improvement in one area of a system can adversely affect another area of the system. The principle of systems approach is closely related to the principle of process approach.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="principle-6-continuous-improvement">Principle 6: Continuous improvement<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principle-6-continuous-improvement" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Continuous improvement is a sustained and on-going effort aimed at improving services, products or processes through incremental improvement over time. Within a health care setting, the following can be used as guidance to continuous improvement:</p>
<ul>
<li>Health institutions/facilities should make continuous improvement of the overall performance as a permanent objective;</li>
<li>Inculcate a culture of continuous improvement of all the processes and systems within every individual. The institutions should employ organisation-wide approach to continuous improvement;</li>
<li>Provide staff with training in the methods and tools of continuous improvement;</li>
<li>Establish goals to guide and measures to track continuous improvement</li>
<li>Recognise and acknowledge improvements.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="principle-7-informed-decision-making">Principle 7: Informed decision making<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principle-7-informed-decision-making" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>At the management level, informed decision making involves using a systematic approach in researching and analysing available evidence on the policy making process. At the patient care level, it involves having systems that ensure that care provided to patients adheres to best practices.</p>
<ul>
<li>This principle ensures that effective decisions are based on the analysis of current and meaningful data and information;</li>
<li>Evidence based decision making also involves ensuring that data and information is sufficiently accurate and reliable and making sure that this data is available and accessible to those who need them;</li>
<li>Evidence based decision making is underpinned by analysing data and information using valid methods and making decisions and taking action based on factual analysis, balanced with experience and intuition.</li>
</ul>
<p>117</p>
<p>Principle 8: Establishment of mutually beneficial relationships</p>
<p>This principle acknowledges that an organisation and its suppliers are interdependent and that mutually beneficial relationships enhance the ability of both to create value. Within health care, the largest supplier is the labour workforce. This principle requires a balance between short-term and long-term gains considerations when establishing relationships, there is establishment of joint development and improvement activities and that there is continuous encouragement and recognition of improvements and achievements by suppliers.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-2-components-of-a-total-quality-management-tqm-system">7.2 Components of a Total Quality Management (TQM) System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-2-components-of-a-total-quality-management-tqm-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The following are components of a TQM: quality assurance; quality assessment; quality control; quality improvement and quality planning/design.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="quality-assurance">Quality Assurance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#quality-assurance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Quality assurance is a series of management activities to ensure that processes, items or services are of the type and quality needed by the users and includes all actions taken to establish, protect, promote and improve quality. Quality assurance includes setting and communicating standards and identifying indicators for performance monitoring and compliance to standards. These standards can come in different forms e.g. protocols, guidelines and specifications. The two main principles in quality assurance are:</p>
<ol>
<li>Fit for purpose  that the goods or services produced should be for the intended purpose;</li>
<li>Right first time  mistakes are eliminated.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="quality-control-qc">Quality control (QC)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#quality-control-qc" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Quality control is a procedure or set of procedures intended to ensure that a manufactured product or performed service adheres to a defined set of quality criteria or meets the requirements of the client or customer. QC is similar to but not identical with quality assurance (QA).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="quality-improvement-qi">Quality improvement (QI)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#quality-improvement-qi" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Quality improvement is defined as an organised, structured process that involves identification of improvement teams to achieve enhancements in product or services.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="quality-planning-design">Quality planning/design<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#quality-planning-design" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Quality planning or quality design is a systematic process that translates quality policy into measurable objectives and requirements and lays down a sequence of steps for realising them within a specified timeframe.</p>
<p>118</p>
<p>7.3 Quality Assurance and Risk Management in the Health Care Setting</p>
<p>Dimensions of Quality</p>
<p>Quality of care has several dimensions. Quality assurance activities address one or more of these dimensions. These dimensions of quality are a useful framework that assists health teams to define and analyse their problems and to measure the extent to which they are meeting programme standards. The dimensions of quality include: technical competence; access to service; effectiveness; interpersonal relations; efficiency; continuity; safety and amenities. The eight dimensions are explained below with their application in the health care setting provided.</p>
<p>Technical Competence</p>
<p>Technical competences include skills, performance and ability of health care workers and support staff to deliver services. It relates to how well providers execute practice guidelines and standards in terms of dependability, accuracy, reliability and consistency for clinical and non-clinical services. Technical competence also relates to the use of materials and equipment required in delivering health care.</p>
<p>Access to Service</p>
<p>This refers to the fact that health services are unhindered by structural, physical, geographic, economic, social, cultural, organisational or linguistic barriers.</p>
<p>Effectiveness</p>
<p>Effectiveness deals with two main issues in the health setting. The first issue is whether the kind of treatment given by the health service leads to desired outcomes and the second one is whether the treatment or care provided is appropriate for the setting it is being provided in.</p>
<p>Interpersonal Relations</p>
<p>The concept of interpersonal relations refers to the nature of interactions between the provider and the clients, the management team and the junior staff, the health system and the community among others.</p>
<p>Efficiency</p>
<p>Efficiency deals with the ability of the health care system to provide best returns for the resources provided.</p>
<p>Continuity</p>
<p>Continuity means that the client receives the complete range of health services that he or she needs without interruption, cessation, or unnecessary repetition of diagnosis or treatment.</p>
<p>119</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="safety">Safety<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#safety" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Safety means minimising the risks of injury, infection, harmful side effects, or other dangers related to service delivery both to the provider and to the client. This deals with prevention of injuries to providers, clients or visitors and prevention of hospital acquired infections.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="amenities">Amenities<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#amenities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Amenities relate to the physical appearance of facilities, personnel and materials as well as to comfort, cleanliness, and privacy. Other amenities may include features that make the wait at the service point more pleasant such as relaxing music, educational or recreational videos and reading materials.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="7-4-risk-management-in-health-care-settings">7.4 Risk Management in Health Care Settings<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-4-risk-management-in-health-care-settings" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Risk is defined as the possibility of a loss or other adverse events that have the potential to interfere with an organisation's ability to fulfil its mandate. Risk management proactively reduces identified risks to an acceptable level by creating a culture founded upon assessment and prevention, rather than reaction and remedy.</p>
<p>Risk management forms an important component of informing and supporting decisions in providing a safe and secure environment for staff and patients. It involves identifying and addressing sources of risk and loss (clinical and operational) and continuously evaluating an organisation's processes, functions and facilities so as to identify potential risks. In the health care setting risk management saves lives, protects patients, visitors and staff and protects the organisation's resources and reputation.</p>
<p>Table 7.1 Examples of Risk Factors in a Hospital Set-up</p>
<table><thead><tr><th> Credentialing  checking whether health care practitioners are properly qualified  Informed consent  Fraud and abuse  Billing and medical record documentation  Infection control  Readmissions  Security  Fire safety  Slip and falls  Medical errors classification  technical errors, diagnosis errors, failure to prevent injury and misuse or maladministration</th><th> Visitor's access to facility  Complaints  Medical staffing  Employees  Patient deaths  Safety assessment for medical applications of radiation  Treatment errors  treatment misadministration's, treatment incidents, treatment accidents  Occupational hazard to staff: musculoskeletal loads, chemical substance, radiation hazard, violence from patients and members of public</th></tr></thead></table>
<p>7.5 Methods and Tools of Measuring Quality</p>
<p>The PDCA (Plan-Do-Check-Act) cycle</p>
<p>The PDCA is a four-step model for assessing problems and enacting solutions with the goal of improving quality. The PDCA is also referred to as the plan-do-study-act (PDSA), Demings cycle or Demings wheel. The PDCA is considered a continuous improvement process represented by a circular graphic and emphasises on processes that incorporate continuous feedback loops to identify sources of error on an on-going basis and provide the data needed to make the necessary changes and improvements.</p>
<p>PDCA follows the concept of the scientific method of first establishing a hypothesis, developing and executing a plan to test the hypothesis, analysing the results and then making modifications to the hypothesis. The cycle is then repeated to continue to assess and improve the quality process. PDCA provides a blueprint for quality assurance managers to properly identify the goals, construct accurate metrics for measuring the goals, evaluate the outcome, and then implement the solutions.</p>
<p>The four steps of PDCA include:</p>
<p>i. Plan - This is an analysis that establishes the objectives or the expected results and creates a plan of action. By starting from the end result and working backwards, each step of the process can be included in the analysis and in the solution. The plan is a critical step in the process of achieving quality outcomes. This stage deconstructs the entire process and allows for the identification of problems and the acknowledgement of what works. Once problems are identified, specific steps can be outlined to address them. The process is repeated with gradual improvements made in each of the iterations. Incremental changes made with each cycle, instead of a one-time approach to attaining perfection, avoid the analysis-paralysis that can ensue when trying to attain perfection on the first pass.</p>
<p>ii. DO- Implementation of the plan</p>
<p>iii. Check: (study) Measurement of the objectives to see how closely they meet expectations. This is an important step as it allows for the adjustment of the plan where necessary.</p>
<p>iv. Act- Implementation of changes identified in the CHECK phase.</p>
<p>The DO and CHECK phase should provide data that shows trends and patterns that can be used to devise a list of solutions that will be carried out in the ACT phase. All change ideas should be tested in a small way first before they can be rolled out. This ensures that there is minimal disruption to the system if the ideas do not work. If the initial small set works then there is confidence to roll it into the whole system.</p>
<p>121</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260113-19dd6690.jpeg" alt="img-18.jpeg">
Figure 7.1 The Plan-Do-Check-Act (PDCA) Cycle</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="data-collection-tools">Data collection tools<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#data-collection-tools" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="i-cause-and-effect-diagrams">i. Cause and effect diagrams<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-cause-and-effect-diagrams" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Cause-and-effect analysis is sometimes referred to as the Ishikawa, or fishbone diagram. In a cause-and-effect diagram, the problem (effect) is stated in a box on the right side of the chart, and likely causes are listed around major headings (bones) that lead to the effect. They can assist in organising the contributing causes to a complex problem Cause-and -effect diagrams do not have a statistical basis but are excellent aids for problem solving and trouble-shooting. They reveal important relationships among various variables and possible causes and provide additional insight into process behaviour.</p>
<p>Figure 7.1 Fishbone Diagram
<img src="assets/images/image-20260113-2081b943.jpeg" alt="img-19.jpeg">
Source: USAID, 2012</p>
<p>ii. Check sheets</p>
<p>These are structured forms designed for collection and analysis of data. A check sheet can be modified for various situations.</p>
<p>How to use a check sheet:</p>
<ul>
<li>Decide what event or problem will be observed and develop operational definitions;</li>
<li>Decide when data will be collected and for how long;</li>
<li>Design the form. Set it up so that data can be recorded simply by making check marks or Xs or similar symbols and so that data do not have to be recopied for analysis;</li>
<li>Label all spaces on the form;</li>
<li>Test the check sheet for a short trial period to be sure it collects the appropriate data and is easy to use;</li>
<li>Each time the targeted event or problem occurs, record data on the check sheet.</li>
</ul>
<p>Table 7.2 Sample Check Sheet: Hospital Infections Occurrences Checklist</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Infection by unit</th><th>Mon</th><th>Tue</th><th>Wed</th><th>Thu</th><th>Fri</th><th>Sat</th><th>Sun</th><th>Total</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Delivery</td><td>III</td><td>I</td><td>III</td><td>III</td><td>III</td><td>I</td><td>I</td><td>20</td></tr><tr><td>Intensive Care</td><td>II</td><td>III</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>6</td></tr><tr><td>Coronary Care</td><td>I</td><td>II</td><td>III</td><td></td><td></td><td>III</td><td>III</td><td>18</td></tr><tr><td>Respiratory Care</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>III</td><td></td><td></td><td>5</td></tr><tr><td>Surgical</td><td>III</td><td></td><td>III</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td>10</td></tr><tr><td>Total</td><td>11</td><td>6</td><td>14</td><td>5</td><td>10</td><td>6</td><td>6</td><td>59</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>iii. Pareto diagrams</p>
<p>A Pareto chart is a display of the frequency of occurrences that helps to show the vital few contributors to a problem so that management can concentrate resources on correcting these major contributors (American Society for Quality, 2000). The Pareto Principle states that: Not all of the causes of a particular phenomenon occur with the same frequency or with the same impact. Such characteristics can be highlighted using Pareto Charts. Pareto charts show the most frequently occurring factors.</p>
<p>Analysis of Pareto charts help to make best use of limited resources by targeting the most important problems to tackle. Concentrate on reducing defects A, B and C (salaries, equipment and transport) since they make up 75% of all defects.</p>
<p>123</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260113-f4beb02e.jpeg" alt="img-20.jpeg">
Figure 7.2 Pareto Chart
Pareto Chart</p>
<p>Source: USAID (2012).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-control-charts">iv. Control charts<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-control-charts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Run chart- Run charts are plots of data, arranged chronologically, that can be used to determine the presence of some types of signals of special cause variation in processes. A centre line (usually the median) is plotted along with the data to test for shifts in the process being studied.</p>
<p>Control chart- A control chart consists of chronological data along with upper and lower control limits that define the limits of common cause variation. It is used to monitor and analyse variation from a process to determine if that process is stable and predictable (comes from common cause variation) or unstable and not predictable (shows signals of special cause variation).</p>
<p>Figure 7.3 Sample Control Cart
<img src="assets/images/image-20260113-f0c2bea5.jpeg" alt="img-21.jpeg">
Source: USAID (2012).</p>
<p>125</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="quality-assessment">Quality Assessment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#quality-assessment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Quality assessment is a component of continuous quality improvement. It is a systematic, ongoing cycle of collecting and analysing evidence of a programmes effectiveness. The information collected is used to evaluate how well the programmes goal is being achieved, and decide what may be done to better achieve the goal. The main purpose of quality assessment is to improve health care quality. Quality assessment should be conducted routinely as part of integral provision of health services.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-quality-assessment">Types of quality assessment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-quality-assessment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Internal  carried by individual working in an organisation. The individual has better understanding of the system but may be biased.</li>
<li>External  should be thoroughly oriented concerning the realities of the system.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-6-standards-in-quality-management">7.6 Standards in Quality Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-6-standards-in-quality-management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="definition">Definition<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#definition" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Standards are a means of describing the level of quality that health care organisations are expected to meet or to aspire to. The performance of organisations can be assessed against this level of quality.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="setting-standards">Setting Standards<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#setting-standards" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Standards are set for comparison of indicators. For example, at least 80 % of all pregnant women attending the antenatal clinic should have their height, blood pressure, HIV status and urine tested.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="characteristics-of-standards">Characteristics of Standards<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characteristics-of-standards" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>i. Should have a scientific basis i.e. their application should ensure application of a certain level of efficiency in health care.
ii. Standards should be relevant for the specific region that they are applied to be realistic to implement and measure.
iii. Should be dynamic  changed when it is necessary;
iv. Should be measurable;</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="levels-of-standardisation">Levels of Standardisation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#levels-of-standardisation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>When formulating standards, a critical decision that must be made is the level at that the standards should be set- minimal, optimal, and achievable. Minimal standards specify what level must be met for quality to be considered acceptable. The implication is that if care does not meet a minimal standard, remedial action is called for. For example, minimum standards</p>
<p>of quality specified in terms of nurse staffing levels, a structural measure of quality. In this case, hospitals that do not meet minimum staffing levels by definition cannot deliver care of acceptable quality (safe care). Optimal standards denote the level of quality that can be reached under the best conditions, typically conditions similar to those under which efficacy is determined. Achievable standards represent the level of performance that should be reached by everyone to whom the standards are being applied</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="domains-of-standards">Domains of Standards<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#domains-of-standards" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The following are domains of standards: Safety; clinical and cost effectiveness; governance; patient focus; accessible and responsive care; care environment and amenities and public health</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="domain-1-safety-for-patient-staff-and-visitors">Domain 1: Safety for patient, staff and visitors<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#domain-1-safety-for-patient-staff-and-visitors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This domain includes measures aimed at reducing adverse drug reactions, reduction of hospital acquired infections, and prevention of Methicillin Resistant Staphylococcus Aureus (MRSA) infections, prevention of needle pricks, waste disposal and falls in the facility among others. There are standards for hospital safety which should be continuously and systematically reviewed and effort should be applied to adhere to the standards.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="domain-2-clinical-and-cost-effectiveness">Domain 2: Clinical and cost effectiveness<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#domain-2-clinical-and-cost-effectiveness" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This domain includes operating within the laid down or agreed clinical guidelines and best practice. This domain also includes ensuring that health workers have up-to-date information on their specialties through regular audit, supervision and continuous education.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="domain-3-governance">Domain 3: Governance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#domain-3-governance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This domain deals with the management style and organisation culture so that quality improvement, quality assurance and patient safety are promoted within the health care institution. On the management style, this includes ensuring that there is accountability.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="domain-4-patient-focus">Domain 4: Patient focus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#domain-4-patient-focus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This domain focuses on ensuring that health care is delivered in partnership with patients, their relatives and also ensuring that their needs are accommodated during care.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="domain-5-accessible-and-responsive-care">Domain 5: Accessible and responsive care<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#domain-5-accessible-and-responsive-care" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This domain focuses on provision of care promptly and prevention of unnecessary delay e.g. waiting, registration, ambulance, payment procedures, unnecessary screening and tests). It also deals with creating mechanisms for ensuring that all members of the population can access health care.</p>
<p>126</p>
<p>127</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="domain-6-care-of-environment-and-amenities">Domain 6: Care of environment and amenities<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#domain-6-care-of-environment-and-amenities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This domain involves provision and maintenance of environments designed to offer comfort and privacy for the patients and safe working environment for health workers.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="domain-7-public-health">Domain 7: Public health<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#domain-7-public-health" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This domain includes efforts and collaborations that promote and improve health of populations but also help bridge health inequalities among different populations by preventing disease i.e. the promotion of good sanitation, environmental management/cleanliness, health seeking behaviour as well as responding to outbreaks swiftly  overlap with infection control.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="international-standardisation">International Standardisation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#international-standardisation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The International Standards Organisation (ISO) 9000 family of standards is related to quality management systems and designed to help organisations ensure that they meet the needs of customers and other stakeholders. The ISO 9001 is the internationally recognised standards for quality management and deals with the requirements that organisations wishing to meet the standard have to fulfil. It specifies requirements for a quality management system that can be used for internal application by organisations or for certification or for contractual purposes. It focuses on the effectiveness of the quality management system in meeting customer requirements and looks at:</p>
<ul>
<li>Processes that create and control products and services within the organisation;</li>
<li>Prescribes certain requirements to ensure that clients needs are met.</li>
</ul>
<p>ISO 9001:2008 is the key internationally agreed standard for quality management systems. It has four elements:</p>
<p>i. Management responsibility: This element ensures that the top management has commitment to quality systems and develops the business objectives to meet customers quality requirements.</p>
<p>ii. Resource management: This element ensures that the human resource, work environment and infrastructure needed to implement quality are in place.</p>
<p>iii. Product realisation: This element ensures that the organisation delivers goods and services that the customers want.</p>
<p>iv. Measurement, analysis and improvement: This element considers that the institution has in place mechanisms to measure customer satisfaction and effectiveness of the whole system.</p>
<p>7.7 The Kenya Quality Model for Health</p>
<p>The Kenya Quality Model for Health envisions improving overall livelihoods of Kenyans through provision of efficient and high quality health care systems. Its development was spearheaded by the Department of Standards and Regulatory services of the Ministry of Health in 2001 as the Kenya Quality Model. The Kenya Quality Model was later reviewed and renamed KQMH. KQMH integrates evidence-based medicine (EBM) with total quality management and patient partnership.</p>
<p><strong>Principles of KQMH</strong></p>
<p>The principles of KQMH are similar to principles of quality management. These are: Leadership; customer orientation; involvement of people and stakeholders; systems approach to management; continuous quality improvement (CQI); and evidence-based decision-making.</p>
<p><strong>Integration of KQMH principles into the Kenyan health system</strong></p>
<p>Successful implementation is based on the Plan-Do-Check-Act (PDCA) methodology. The following steps are applied:</p>
<ul>
<li>Health managers use KQMH checklists to assess performance of the health system against KQMH standards and opportunities for improvement are identified;</li>
<li>The science of improvement is used to ensure realisation of KQMH standards.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Dimensions of the Kenya health systems</strong></p>
<p>KQMH is anchored on twelve (12) dimensions which are the resources, processes and outcomes that are vital to ensuring that quality service is delivered. The KQMH dimensions are based on the Donabedian Model of structure process and outcome listed above.</p>
<p><strong>Structure</strong></p>
<p>In the KQMH structure, dimensions are: Leadership, human resource, policy standards and guidelines, facilities, supplies, equipment, transportation, referral systems, hospital records and health management information systems (HMIS) and financial management</p>
<p><strong>Process</strong></p>
<p>Process dimension is divided into four other sub-dimensions namely: The client-provider interaction, continuous quality improvement, programme management for reproductive health, extended programme for immunisation, HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis and IMCI (integrated management of childhood illnesses) and management of none communicable disease.</p>
<p>128</p>
<p>129</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="outcome-results">Outcome (results)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#outcome-results" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Outcome dimension is also divided into four other sub-dimensions namely user-client satisfaction, performance of facility and primary health care, staff satisfaction and societal satisfaction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="implementation-of-kqmh">Implementation of KQMH<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#implementation-of-kqmh" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>KQMH has five implementation phases:</p>
<ul>
<li>Phase 1: Preparation</li>
<li>Phase 2: Introduction</li>
<li>Phase 3: Implementation</li>
<li>Phase 4: Expanding</li>
<li>Phase 5: Sustaining / Maintenance</li>
</ul>
<p>Elements of KQMH include:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-work-environment-improvement-wei">i. Work environment improvement (WEI)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-work-environment-improvement-wei" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This is a structured programme that seeks to achieve cleanliness, organisation and standardisation at the work place. WEI uses the 5S approach which is a Japanese model and includes: Seiri  Sorting, Seiton  Set, Seiso  Shining, Seiketsu  Standardising and Shitsuke  Sustaining.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ii-setting-up-of-quality-improvement-teams-qit">ii. Setting up of quality improvement teams (QIT)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-setting-up-of-quality-improvement-teams-qit" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>QITs are teams formed in a health facility to take the lead in implementing quality improvement activities. The QIT includes members of the health facility management team and individuals from middle management. The QIT is responsible for the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Training health facility staff on KQMH tools and methods;</li>
<li>Conducting situation analysis;</li>
<li>Implementation of KQMH;</li>
<li>Conducting periodic monitoring of improvement activities;</li>
<li>Feeding back to the work improvement team (WIT);</li>
<li>Documentation of KQMH activities;</li>
<li>Reviewing of progress and action plans;</li>
<li>Provision of quarterly reports to the hospital management team.</li>
</ul>
<p>iii. Work improvement teams (WIT)</p>
<p>These are composed of small groups of first-line facility employees who continually control and improve quality of their networks, products and services. The following are the main roles of WIT:</p>
<ul>
<li>Promote improvement activities in the health facility;</li>
<li>Identify, analyse and solve work improvement problems;</li>
<li>Train others on quality management;</li>
<li>Monitor the progress of quality improvement.</li>
</ul>
<p>iv. Tools for implementation of continuous quality improvement in KQMH</p>
<p>The following tools/ processes are used in KQMH either alone or in combination for promotion of quality improvement:</p>
<ul>
<li>Alignment: Hospital equipment, tools, files etc. are arranged in an orderly manner.</li>
<li>Numbering/alphabetical coding: Files and equipment are indexed for easy retrieval.</li>
<li>Sorting: All the items in a facility are grouped into three categories namely necessary, maybe necessary or unnecessary items. Unnecessary items are often discarded.</li>
<li>Safety signs: Signs are installed in all the areas to warn workers or visitors about hazardous materials. International or national safety standardised signs are used. Signage is also recommended for identifying different places in a facility.</li>
<li>Colour coding is used to distinguish hazardous from non-hazardous waste. Waste is also segregated into separate bins.</li>
<li>Use of labelling and symbols.</li>
<li>Zoning: This is whereby positions for storing specific items are marked so as to easily identify when these items are missing or out of place.</li>
</ul>
<p>7.8 Measuring Client Satisfaction</p>
<p>Client satisfaction is a measure of the proportion of customers whose reported experience with the goods or services provided by an organisation exceeds a pre-specified approval rating. Client satisfaction assessment in a hospital setting is conducted through patient surveys. They are important in assessing hospital outcomes and for assessing the human/interpersonal aspect of health care quality. Simply put, client satisfaction surveys measures the gap between expected service and the experience of the service.</p>
<p>130</p>
<p>Advantages of client satisfaction assessment</p>
<ul>
<li>They can provide information on the effectiveness of the service process or other processes;</li>
<li>They can give a measure of the facilitys performance in the past and a guide to changes for the future;</li>
<li>They can be used as a marketing tool by making clients aware of the range of services available;</li>
<li>They have the potential to reduce the chance of complaints;</li>
<li>They are part of the service process itself, i.e. they establish or reinforce contact.</li>
</ul>
<p>Ways of conducting client surveys</p>
<ul>
<li>Interview existing patients;</li>
<li>Conduct interviews on patients who have been discharged from hospital before they leave;</li>
<li>Observation of clients. We often see good and bad actions such as clients being left waiting in the reception. Take note of the details. Use them as examples, adopting a remedial preventative style with colleagues and fee earners rather than a punitive approach;</li>
<li>Interview occasional clients if and when opportunities arise;</li>
<li>Reflect carefully on complaints to remedy not to punish. Remember you want to know about these;</li>
<li>Listen to client comments whether good or bad. Repeat them to your colleagues and consider the implications.</li>
</ul>
<p>Factors that influence what clients expect of a service are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Past experience  previous encounter with the hospital;</li>
<li>External influences  such as the media;</li>
<li>Personal needs  some clients might have special needs such as religious dietary requirements which are beyond the standard requirements;</li>
<li>Word of mouth  experiences, especially negative ones, are easily shared amongst communities. This might influence the expectation of a client.</li>
</ul>
<p>131</p>
<p>132</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="factors-that-influence-how-patients-experience-the-service-are">Factors that influence how patients experience the service are:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#factors-that-influence-how-patients-experience-the-service-are" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ul>
<li>Tangibles  the quality of equipment and of the physical surroundings;</li>
<li>Reliability  the ability to accurately perform the service offered;</li>
<li>Responsiveness  willingness to assist clients;</li>
<li>Assurance  ability of the service provider to be knowledgeable and to inspire confidence and trust;</li>
<li>Empathy  ability to care and display compassion towards clients;</li>
<li>Access  the cost and time for patients to use a service as well as hospital hours.</li>
</ul>

<p>To introduce students to financial management and resource mobilisation</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="objectives">Objectives<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#objectives" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>By the end of this module, the student should be able to:</p>
<ol>
<li>Define public financial management;</li>
<li>Identify various processes involved in financial management;</li>
<li>Identify and discuss financial recording keeping at the health facility level;</li>
<li>Identify and discuss various forms of resource mobilisation for health service provision.</li>
</ol>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lesson-plan-guide">Lesson Plan Guide:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lesson-plan-guide" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<table><thead><tr><th>Session</th><th>Time (Hours)</th><th>Content/Topic</th><th>Lesson Objectives</th><th>Lecturer Evaluation/Remarks</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>Financial management in the Kenya public health sector</td><td>Define financial management</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Discuss government financial accounting systems</td><td>Comments regarding time adequacy and students understanding and perceptions.</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>2</td><td>2</td><td>Public Sector Accounting processes, procedures and documentation</td><td>Discuss various public sector accounting processes, procedures and documentation</td><td>As above</td></tr><tr><td>3</td><td>2</td><td>Health financing</td><td>Describe public health financing in Kenya and identify various sources of funds</td><td>As above</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="8-1-financial-management">8.1 Financial Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8-1-financial-management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Financial management entails planning, organising, controlling and monitoring the financial resources of an organisation to achieve objectives. Financial management in the public sector is governed by:</p>
<ul>
<li>The Public Financial Management Act. The objective of this Act is to ensure that public finances are managed both at the national level and the county level in accordance with the constitution of Kenya.</li>
<li>Government financial regulations and procedures. This contains financial regulations and procedures that govern government finances.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="principles-of-financial-management">Principles of Financial Management<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principles-of-financial-management" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is useful to identify a series of good practice principles which can be used as a standard in developing proper financial management systems. These principles provide a high-level guide for staff members.</p>
<p>136</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="consistency">Consistency<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#consistency" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The financial policies and systems must be consistent over time. This promotes efficient operations and transparency especially in financial reporting. This does not mean that systems may not be refined to cope with a changing organisation. Inconsistent approaches to financial management could be a sign that the financial situation is being manipulated.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="accountability">Accountability<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#accountability" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The organisation must explain how it has used its resources and what it has achieved as a result to all stakeholders, including beneficiaries. All stakeholders have the right to know how their funds and authority have been used. Organisations have an operational, moral and legal duty to explain their decisions and actions, and submit their financial reports to scrutiny. Accountability is the moral or legal duty placed on an individual, group or organisation to explain how funds, equipment or authority given by a third party has been used.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="transparency">Transparency<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transparency" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The organisation must be open about its work, making information about its activities and plans available to relevant stakeholders. This includes preparing accurate, complete and timely financial reports and making them accessible to stakeholders, including beneficiaries. If an organisation is not transparent, then it may give the impression of having something to hide.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="viability">Viability<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viability" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>To be financially viable, a health facilitys expenditure must be kept in balance with incoming funds, both at the operational and the strategic levels. Viability is a measure of financial continuity and security. The HMT and HMC should prepare a financing strategy to show how the organisation will meet all of its financial obligations and deliver its strategic plan.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="integrity">Integrity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#integrity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>On a personal level, individuals must operate with honesty and propriety. For example, members of the HMT and HMC members are expected to lead by example in following policy and procedures and declare any personal interests that might conflict with their official duties. The integrity of financial records and reports is dependent on accuracy and completeness of financial records.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="stewardship">Stewardship<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stewardship" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The HMC is expected to take good care of the financial resources it is entrusted with and make sure that they are used for the purpose intended, this is known as financial stewardship. The HMC has overall responsibility for this. In practice, financial stewardship is achieved</p>
<p>through careful strategic planning, assessing financial risks and setting up appropriate systems and controls.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="accounting-terminology">Accounting Terminology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#accounting-terminology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-break-even-analysis">i. Break-even analysis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-break-even-analysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Break-even analysis is a technique widely used by production management and management accountants. It is based on categorising production costs between those which are variable (costs that change when the production output changes) and those that are fixed (costs not directly related to the volume of production). Total variable and fixed costs are compared with sales revenue in order to determine the level of sales volume, sales value or production at which the business makes neither a profit nor a loss (the break-even point).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ii-differential-analysis">ii. Differential analysis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-differential-analysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Differential analysis involves analysing the different costs and benefits arising from alternative solutions to the situation. Relevant costs and revenues are those that differ between alternatives. Differential cost is the amount by which relevant costs differ between two alternatives. Differential revenue is the amount by which relevant revenues differ between two alternatives. The alternative resulting in the greatest positive difference between future revenues and future expenses (costs) should be selected when using differential analysis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iii-capital-investment-decisions">iii. Capital investment decisions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-capital-investment-decisions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The objective of making capital investment decisions is to maximise wealth. To do this we need to invest in those projects that will give the correct rate of return for the risk involved. The process of making an investment decision entails the following: identifying suitable investment opportunities, deciding on the best selection method, identifying the cash flows that will be generated by those investments, discounting them at the correct cost of capital and choosing the best one or ones from those available.</p>
<p>Discount the cash flows at the appropriate market determines opportunity cost of capital. There are various methods for evaluating projects: payback, accounting rate of return (ARR), internal rate of return (IRR) and the net present value (NPV). The NPV is the best method among all of them. The NPV is the net difference between the present value of the investments net cash inflows and the investments cost (cash outflows) discounted at the companys required rate of return (hurdle) rate. The investment must meet or exceed the hurdle rate to be acceptable.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iv-financial-controls">iv. Financial Controls<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-financial-controls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A system of controls, checks and balances is collectively referred to as internal controls. It is put in place to safeguard an organisations assets and manage internal risk. Its purpose is to</p>
<p>137</p>
<p>deter opportunistic theft or fraud and to detect errors and omissions in the accounting records. An effective internal control system also protects staff involved in financial tasks.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="8-2-the-government-accountant-general-and-treasury">8.2 The Government Accountant General and Treasury<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8-2-the-government-accountant-general-and-treasury" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The Accountant General (AG) is a department which facilitates planning, developing and implementing government accounting policies, systems and procedures. It monitors revenue collection in liaison with the Economic Affairs Department (EAD) and expenditure as approved by Parliament. The two departments are based at Treasury. Treasury is in charge of establishing procedures and systems of effective management of government money and property. It is also responsible for the establishment of accounting procedures and systems.
