<table><thead><tr><th>Session</th><th>Time (Hours)</th><th>Content/Topic</th><th>Lesson Objectives</th><th>Lecturer Evaluation/Remarks</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>Health policy and reforms</td><td>To introduce students to the role of health policy and reforms in the health sector</td><td>Comments regarding time adequacy and students understanding and perceptions</td></tr><tr><td>2</td><td>2</td><td>Health policy implementation</td><td>To identify the various components of current health sector policy objectives</td><td>As above</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="10-1-aim-of-health-policy-and-reforms">10.1 Aim of Health Policy and Reforms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#10-1-aim-of-health-policy-and-reforms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Health policy refers to decisions, plans, and actions that are undertaken to achieve specific health care goals within a society. The purpose of a broad public health policy is to protect the health of populations. According to the World Health Organisation (1978), health is a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being and not merely the absence of disease or infirmity. WHO has further proclaimed that the health of all the people is fundamental to the attainment of peace and security and is dependent upon the fullest cooperation of individuals and states, and that the enjoyment of the highest attainable standards of health is one of the fundamental rights of every human being.</p>
<p>On attaining independence, the government committed itself to providing free- health services as part of its development strategy to alleviate poverty and improve the welfare and productivity of the nation. The aim of the health sector policy and reforms is to develop and expand health services and facilities in terms of spatial coverage, training of personnel and tertiary health care delivery services.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="10-2-health-indicators">10.2 Health Indicators<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#10-2-health-indicators" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The health status of the population can be assessed by a number of indicators including infant, child and maternal mortality and morbidity rates, crude death rate, life expectancy at</p>
<p>birth, and the number of medical staff and facilities available per unit of population. These are the basic indicators of a country's health, socio-economic situation and quality of life.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="infant-mortality-rate">Infant Mortality Rate<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#infant-mortality-rate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Infant mortality rate is the probability of dying between birth and exactly one year of age, expressed per 1,000 live births. Under-five mortality rate is the probability of dying between birth and exactly five years of age, expressed per 1,000 live births.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="life-expectancy">Life Expectancy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#life-expectancy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Life expectancy at birth is the number of years a new born infant would live if prevailing factors of mortality at the time of birth were to stay the same throughout the child's life.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="crude-birth-and-death-rates">Crude Birth and Death Rates<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#crude-birth-and-death-rates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Crude birth rate is the number of births per 1,000. Crude death rate is defined as the number of deaths per 1,000 and is calculated as follows:</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mtext>Crude&nbsp;death&nbsp;rate</mtext><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mtext>Number&nbsp;of&nbsp;deaths</mtext><mtext>Estimated&nbsp;midyear&nbsp;population</mtext></mfrac><mo></mo><mn>1000</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\text{Crude death rate} = \frac{\text{Number of deaths}}{\text{Estimated midyear population}} \times 1000</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Crude&nbsp;death&nbsp;rate</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.2519em; vertical-align: -0.8804em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.3714em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Estimated&nbsp;midyear&nbsp;population</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord text"><span class="mord">Number&nbsp;of&nbsp;deaths</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s"></span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8804em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1000</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>Both crude birth and death rates are important determinants of population size. An increase in crude birth rate may lead to an increase in population size if the crude death rate remains constant.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fertility-rates">Fertility Rates<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fertility-rates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Total fertility rate is the number of children a woman would have by the end of her childbearing years if she were to pass through those years bearing children. Analysis of fertility rates plays an important role in determining population growth rate, which in turn helps in planning for social provisioning.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nutritional-status">Nutritional Status<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nutritional-status" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The nutritional well-being of young children reflects household, community and national investments in family health and contributes in both direct and indirect ways to the country's development. The nutritional status of children is summarised using anthropometric indices (height and weight) which reflect past deprivation.</p>
<p>Malnutrition is a major source of ill health and premature death. Undernourished people are those whose food intake is insufficient to meet their minimum energy requirements. Stunting (insufficient height for age) is an indication of cumulative deficient growth linked to long-term deprivation of both food and non-food requirements. Wasting (insufficient weight for height) associated with short-term deprivations changes rapidly and is sensitive to acute food deprivation and morbidity. Low weight for age indicates chronic and acute under nutrition.</p>
<p>184</p>
<p>185</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="10-3-structure-of-the-health-care-system">10.3 Structure of the Health Care System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#10-3-structure-of-the-health-care-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The level of a nations development depends upon the economic and social conditions and the extent and quality of health services provided to the population. Therefore, the health care we have today is a result of policies made some years ago. The development of health care system in Kenya goes back to the pre-colonial era.</p>
<p>In 1901, a medical department was created as one of the civil departments of the central administration. This was the first step towards establishment of colonial medical organisations supported and controlled by the state. In 1903, medical administrators were requested, first, to preserve the health of the European Community, second, to keep the African and Asiatic labour force in good working condition and third, to prevent the spread of tropical diseases.</p>
<p>Medical education in Kenya started in 1967 when the University of East Africa established a faculty of medicine at University College, Nairobi, which in 1970 became the University of Nairobi. After independence, the government continued to expand health facilities in the country. At independence, Kenya inherited a three-tier health system in which the central government provided services at district, provincial and national levels; missionaries provided health services at sub-district levels; and local government provided services in urban areas. This system operated until 1970 when the government established a system of comprehensive rural health services in which health centres became the focal points for comprehensive provision of preventive, promotive and curative services.</p>
<p>Today, alongside government services, non-profit and FBOs organisations and NGOs provide health services at delivery points that range from dispensaries to hospitals. The governments health care delivery system is pyramidal, with the national referral facilities at Kenyatta National Hospital (Nairobi) and Moi Teaching and Referral Hospital (Eldoret) forming the peak, followed by provincial, district and sub-district hospitals, with health centres and dispensaries forming the base.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="10-4-health-policies-and-objectives">10.4 Health Policies and Objectives<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#10-4-health-policies-and-objectives" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The main mandate of a health system is to ensure that people enjoy long lives that are relatively free from the burden of disease and ill health. Health policies and strategies are aimed at reducing incidence of disease and improving the health status of Kenyans. Health policy in Kenya revolves around two critical issues, namely: how to deliver a basic package of quality health services to a growing workforce and their dependants and how to finance and manage those services in a way that guarantees their availability, accessibility and affordability to those in most need. The overall goal of the government is to promote and improve the health status of all Kenyans by making all health services more effective, accessible and affordable.</p>
<p>In all its development and sectoral plans, the governments main objectives for development of health services since independence have been:</p>
<ul>
<li>Strengthening and carrying out measures for eradication, prevention and control of disease. Such measures include protection of the environment against health hazards, vector disease control, immunisation against disease, early detection and treatment of diseases and health education;</li>
<li>Provision for adequate and effective diagnostic, therapeutic and rehabilitative services for the whole population at hospitals, health centres, dispensaries and mobile units;</li>
<li>Promotion and development of biomedical and health services research as a means of identifying improved and cost effective methods for the protection of the health of the people.</li>
</ul>
<p>The main health policies in Kenya include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Increasing coverage and accessibility of health services in rural areas;</li>
<li>Further consolidating urban and rural curative and preventive and promotive services;</li>
<li>Increasing emphasis on maternal and child health and family planning services in order to reduce morbidity, mortality and fertility;</li>
<li>Strengthening Ministry of Health management capacities with emphasis at the county level;</li>
<li>Increasing inter-ministerial coordination of health service delivery; and</li>
<li>Increasing alternative financing mechanisms.</li>
</ul>
<p>The Ministry of Health is the main provider of health services in the country. It has the following functions:</p>
<ul>
<li>Formulation and implementation of a national health policy;</li>
<li>Preparation and implementation of national health development plans;</li>
<li>Organisation and administration of central health services;</li>
<li>Development of health acts and regulations;</li>
<li>Training of health and allied personnel;</li>
<li>Promotion of medical science and maintenance of medical and health standards;</li>
<li>Liaison and coordination with other government departments and NGO agencies; and</li>
<li>Internal health regulations.</li>
</ul>
<p>186</p>
<p>187</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="10-5-health-policy-and-the-constitution-of-kenya-2010">10.5 Health Policy and the Constitution of Kenya 2010<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#10-5-health-policy-and-the-constitution-of-kenya-2010" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The Constitution of Kenya 2010 provides an overarching conducive legal framework for ensuring a comprehensive and people-driven health services delivery. It provides for a rights-based approach to health whereby every person has the right to the highest attainable standard of health. It further indicates that a person shall not be denied emergency medical treatment and that the State shall provide appropriate social security to persons who are unable to support themselves and their dependants.</p>
<p>The Constitution singles out health care for specific groups such as children and persons living with disabilities. In addition, the underlying determinants of the right to health such as adequate housing, food, clean safe water, social security and education are also guaranteed in the Constitution. The current Health Policy therefore seeks to make the realisation of the right to health by all Kenyans a reality.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="10-6-kenya-health-policy-framework-2012-2030">10.6 Kenya Health Policy Framework 2012-2030<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#10-6-kenya-health-policy-framework-2012-2030" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This Kenya Health Policy 2012-2030 represents the government's commitment towards improving the health of the people of Kenya by significantly reducing ill health. The Policy defines the health goal, objectives including strategies, guiding principles and orientations aimed at achieving the health agenda in Kenya.</p>
<p>The Kenya Health Policy 2012-2030 provides guidance to the health sector in terms of identifying and outlining the requisite activities in achieving the government's health goals. The policy is aligned to Kenya's Vision 2030 (Kenya's national development agenda), the Constitution of Kenya and global health commitments and uses a three-pronged framework (comprehensive, balanced and coherent) to define policy direction as shown in Figure 10.2.</p>
<p>The goal of Kenya Health Policy 2012-2030 is attaining the highest possible standard of health in a manner responsive to the needs of the population. The Policy focuses on six objectives, and seven orientations to attain the overall government's health goals. The implementation of the policy will be done through five-year medium-term strategic plans.</p>
<p>Table 10.1 Kenya Health Policy 2012-2030 Framework for Policy Directions
<img src="assets/images/image-20260113-7cf16e03.jpeg" alt="img-29.jpeg">
Source: Kenya Health Policy 2012-2030.</p>
<p>Figure 10.2 Health Policy Framework: 2012-2030
<img src="assets/images/image-20260113-6892ef29.jpeg" alt="img-30.jpeg">
Source: Kenya Health Policy, 2012.</p>
<p>189</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="policy-objectives">Policy Objectives<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#policy-objectives" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Eliminate communicable conditions</li>
<li>Halt and reverse the rising burden of non-communicable conditions</li>
<li>Reduce the burden of violence and injuries</li>
<li>Provide essential health care</li>
<li>Minimise exposure to health risk factors</li>
<li>Strengthen collaboration with other sectors that have an impact on health</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="policy-orientations">Policy orientations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#policy-orientations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Policy orientations define how the health sector will organise itself to facilitate attainment of the health objectives. The orientations are organised around the following Health System Building Blocks:</p>
<p>i. Service delivery systems: How health service delivery will be organised;
ii. Leadership and governance: How health service delivery will be managed;
iii. Health workforce: The human resources required for the provision of health services;
iv. Health financing: The systems needed to ensure adequate resources for service provision;
v. Health products and technologies: The essential medicines, medical supplies, vaccines, health technologies and public health commodities required in provision of services;
vi. Health information: Systems for generation, analysis, dissemination, and utilisation of health related information;
vii. Health infrastructure: The physical infrastructure, equipment, transport, and information communication technology needed for delivery of health services.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="references-and-recommended-further-reading">References and Recommended Further Reading<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#references-and-recommended-further-reading" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="module-11-law-and-ethics-in-health-care">MODULE 11: LAW AND ETHICS IN HEALTH CARE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#module-11-law-and-ethics-in-health-care" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lesson-plan-guide">Lesson Plan Guide:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lesson-plan-guide" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<table><thead><tr><th>Session</th><th>Time (Hours)</th><th>Content/Topic</th><th>Lesson Objectives</th><th>Lecturer Evaluation/Remarks</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1</td><td>2</td><td>Health professionals legal responsibilities</td><td>To introduce students to health professionals legal obligations and responsibilities</td><td>Comments regarding time adequacy and students understanding and perceptions.</td></tr><tr><td>2</td><td>2</td><td>Ethical issues and theories in modern Health care</td><td>To introduce students to ethics in health service delivery</td><td>As above</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="11-1-health-professionals-legal-responsibilities">11.1 Health Professionals Legal Responsibilities<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#11-1-health-professionals-legal-responsibilities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Patients have the right to receive considerate and respectful health care. It is the health care providers legal and ethical responsibility to know and respect the patients rights. Professionally health care workers have specific legal responsibilities that regulate their particular profession. Adhering to legal regulations is vital for the health care workers own protection, the protection of their employer and more importantly, the safety and well-being of the patient. Failure to observe legal and ethical obligations leads to negligence or malpractice.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="medical-negligence">Medical Negligence<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-negligence" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Medical negligence, according to Mosbys Medical Dictionary (8th edition), can be defined as the commission of an act that a prudent person would not have done or the omission of a duty that a prudent person would have fulfilled, resulting in injury or harm to a patient.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="medical-malpractice">Medical Malpractice<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-malpractice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Medical malpractice means bad, wrong or injudicious treatment of a patient professionally which results in injury, unnecessary suffering or death. Malpractice and negligence may occur through omission of a necessary act as well as commission of an unwise or negligent act. This may be in the form of misdiagnosis, wrong decisions and treatment, prescription errors and medical or surgical complications, all of which may result in suffering, permanent injury or death.</p>
<p>192</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="regulation">Regulation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#regulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>In Kenya, medical, nursing and midwifery practices are regulated by statutory authorities, including the Medical Practitioners and Dentists Board, the Nursing Council of Kenya, the Clinical Officers Council and the Pharmacy and Poisons Board. These bodies are obliged to protect members of the public by ensuring that medical practitioners including dentists, nurses and midwives, clinical officers and pharmacists are properly qualified, that they perform their services to patients with skill and diligence and observe at all times high moral and ethical standards. Health care professionals are expected to know and follow the laws regulating their profession, license or registration.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="applicable-laws">Applicable laws<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#applicable-laws" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Legal responsibilities in the health sector are interpreted through civil or criminal law. Civil law deals with legal relationships between people and protection of a person's rights. Criminal law deals with wrongs against a person, property or society, practising without the required licence, theft and murder among others. Many of the wrong doings in health care are civil wrongs. However, they can lead to legal action.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="compliance">Compliance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#compliance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The following are basic guidelines on how to comply with appropriate laws and procedures:</p>
<ul>
<li>Protect the patient from exposure (heat or cold);</li>
<li>Knock and pause before entering a room;</li>
<li>Draw curtains or close door when providing care;</li>
<li>Leave while visitors are with the patient;</li>
<li>Do not listen when patients make phone calls;</li>
<li>Abide by the rules of confidentiality;</li>
<li>Do not discuss the patient's condition with anyone outside of work;</li>
<li>Be aware of your surroundings and do not discuss a patient within areas others could overhear (lifts, cafeteria, corridors, parking lot, etc).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="privileged-communication">Privileged Communication<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#privileged-communication" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>All information given to health personnel by a patient is considered privileged communication, and by law must be kept confidential. However, certain information is exempt by law and must be reported. This includes:</p>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Births and deaths;</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Injuries caused by violence requiring police intervention (assault and battery, abuse, stabbings);</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Drug abuse;</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Chronic diseases.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-care-records">Health Care Records<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-care-records" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Belongs to the health care provider;</li>
<li>Patient has right to obtain copy of any information in record;</li>
<li>Can be a legal record in court of law;</li>
<li>Must be properly maintained, kept confidential and maintained for amount of time required by state;</li>
<li>When destroyed after time permits, must be burned or shredded to maintain confidentiality.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="patient-instructions">Patient Instructions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#patient-instructions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="advance-directives">Advance directives<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#advance-directives" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>These are a patients instructions, usually relating to end-of-life issues regarding what measures should or should not be used to prolong life if their condition is terminal e.g. CPR, ventilator, feeding tube, etc. Advance directives frequently results in a do not resuscitate (DNR) order. Advance directives are legally binding documents. They must be signed when the individual is competent and witnessed by two adults who will not benefit from the death. There are two main types of advance directives:</p>
<p>i. Durable Power of Attorney (POA) for health care</p>
<p>This is a document permitting an individual (principal) to appoint another person (agent) to make any decisions regarding health care if the principal is unable to make those decisions. Usually POAs are given to spouses or adult children or another adult. The POA must be signed by the principal, agent, and two adult witnesses.</p>
<p>ii. Living will</p>
<p>This is a document allowing individuals to state what measures should or should not be used to prolong life if their condition is terminal e.g. CPR, ventilator, feeding tube, etc. This frequently results in a do not resuscitate (DNR) order.</p>
<p>193</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="professional-standards-and-code-of-conduct">Professional Standards and Code of Conduct<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#professional-standards-and-code-of-conduct" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Professional standards help meet legal responsibilities, ethics and patients' rights. By following certain standards at all times, the health care worker can protect themselves, their employer and the patient. Some of the basic standards are:</p>
<p>iii. Perform only those procedures for which you have been trained and are legally permitted to do (scope of practice);</p>
<p>iv. If asked to perform procedure for which you are not qualified, decline;</p>
<p>v. Use approved, correct methods while performing any procedure</p>
<p>vi. Follow procedure manual</p>
<p>vii. Obtain correct authorisation before performing any procedure;</p>
<p>viii. Identify patient and obtain consent before performing any procedure;</p>
<p>ix. Check wrist band if available: State patients name clearly and repeat if necessary, ask patient their name and birth date;</p>
<p>x. If patient refuses, do not perform procedure;</p>
<p>xi. Obtain written consent where needed;</p>
<p>xii. Observe all safety precautions;</p>
<p>xiii. Keep all information confidential;</p>
<p>xiv. Think before you speak and watch everything you say;</p>
<p>xv. Treat all patients equally;</p>
<p>xvi. Accept no tips or bribes for care;</p>
<p>xvii. If error occurs or you make a mistake, report it immediately to your supervisor;</p>
<p>xviii. Behave professionally in dress, language, manners and actions.</p>
<p>194</p>

When she went two weeks past the due date, he admitted her at a private hospital for induction of labour, but for three days labour did not set in. <div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="policies-and-procedures">Policies and Procedures<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#policies-and-procedures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Health care workers must be familiar with their employer's policies and procedures. Policies and procedures are the guidelines that provide information about employment terms, work place procedures, quality control etc. Technical procedures tell you how to complete tasks the way your employer wants them done. There may be procedures for the following:</p>
<p>How to take a temperature;
How to give an enema;
How to fill out forms;
How to package and wrap trays;
Standard operating procedures;
Treatment protocols.</p>
<p>These guidelines assure that the health care worker performs their jobs correctly. It is important to always follow a health facility's policies and procedures. Doing this will protect your patients, co-workers, employer and yourself.</p>
<p>199</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="11-2-ethical-issues-and-theories-in-modern-health-care">11.2 Ethical Issues and Theories in Modern Health Care<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#11-2-ethical-issues-and-theories-in-modern-health-care" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Ethics is a set of moral principles and a code for behaviour governing an individuals actions with other individuals and within society. Ethics is a critical reflection about morality  what is believed to be right and good. Medicine and technology are rapidly changing and offering choices to health professionals. Although challenging and even exciting, the choices can be difficult. For example, should medications known to be effective be withheld from a patient because it is thought they are incompetent or do not have the means to store or manage the medication properly?</p>
<p>In modern health care and research, value conflicts arise where there often appears to be no clear consensus as to the right thing to do. These conflicts present problems requiring moral decisions that necessitate a choice between two or more alternatives.</p>
<p>Examples:</p>
<ul>
<li>Should a parent have a right to refuse immunisations for his or her child?</li>
<li>Does public safety supersede an individuals right?</li>
<li>Should children with serious birth defects be kept alive?</li>
<li>Should a woman be allowed an abortion for any reason?</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ethical-dilemmas-and-theories">Ethical dilemmas and theories<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ethical-dilemmas-and-theories" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ethical-dilemma">Ethical dilemma<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ethical-dilemma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This is a value conflict with no clear consensus as to the right thing to do. It is conflict between moral obligations that are difficult to reconcile and require moral reasoning. Situations necessitating a choice between two equal (usually undesirable) alternatives. Modern health care technology has created many ethical dilemmas. For example:</p>
<ul>
<li>Assisted suicide  is it justified in certain patients?</li>
<li>Stem cell research  should aborted foetuses be used?</li>
<li>Should a patient be permitted to smoke marijuana if it eases pain or effects of chemotherapy?</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="deontology-non-consequentialism-theory">Deontology / Non-consequentialism Theory<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#deontology-non-consequentialism-theory" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This is derived from the Greek word Deon, meaning duty. Under this theory, some acts are right or wrong independent of their consequences. The theory is based on the concept of duty. It is premised on ones obligation and on that basis seeks to determine what is ethical by answering the question: What should I do and why should I do it?</p>
<p>200</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="illustration-deontology-a-duty">Illustration: Deontology: A duty<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#illustration-deontology-a-duty" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Anita, a practitioner, believes she has a duty to give cardiac clients detailed information on the pathology involved in their condition even though the client has indicated that they are not ready or may be terrified to hear the information causing the client distress.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="consequentialism-theory">Consequentialism Theory<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#consequentialism-theory" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Also called Teleological theory. Actions are determined and justified by the consequence of the act. Consequentialists consider all the consequences of what they are about to do prior to deciding a right action. This also answers the question: What should I do and why should I do it?</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="illustration-consequentialism-action">Illustration: Consequentialism: Action<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#illustration-consequentialism-action" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Had Anita respected the wishes of her clients, she would have given them only the information which would have been a benefit to them and not caused them undue stress. She would have been motivated by her desire to do good (beneficence), rather than her sense of duty. This would amount to deontological betrayal.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="utilitarian-theory">Utilitarian Theory<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#utilitarian-theory" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Considers the greatest good for the largest number of people. Also answers the question: What should I do and why should I do it? The problem with employing Utilitarian theory is determining who decides the definition of "greatest" and "good".</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="intuitionism-theory">Intuitionism Theory<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intuitionism-theory" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Resolves ethical dilemmas by appealing to one's intuition, a moral faculty of a person which directly knows what is right or wrong. A gut feeling of knowing what is right. The difficulty with intuitionism is in deciding whose moral position is more valid.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="rights-based-theory">Rights Based Theory<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#rights-based-theory" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This theory resolves ethical dilemmas by first determining what rights or moral claims are involved and take precedence. Consider the abortion debate, personal  mom vs. foetus/child, societal- women's choice vs. potential life of the unborn).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="virtue-ethics-theory">Virtue Ethics Theory<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#virtue-ethics-theory" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Contrary to other ethical theories, virtue ethics tells us what kind of person one ought to be, rather than what they do. The focus is on the character (goodness) of the person.</p>
<p>201</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="11-3-basic-rules-of-medical-ethics">11.3 Basic Rules of Medical Ethics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#11-3-basic-rules-of-medical-ethics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>Put saving of life and promotion of health above all else;</li>
<li>Make every effort to keep patient as comfortable as possible and to preserve life when possible;</li>
<li>Respect patients choice to die peacefully and with dignity (advanced directive);</li>
<li>Treat all patients equally, avoid bias, prejudice and discrimination;</li>
<li>Provide care for all persons to the best of your ability;</li>
<li>Maintain competent level of skill consistent with occupation;</li>
<li>Maintain confidentiality;</li>
<li>Gossiping about patients is ethically wrong;</li>
<li>Avoid immoral, unethical or illegal practice;</li>
<li>Show loyalty to patients, co-workers and employer;</li>
<li>Be sincere, honest and caring.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="suggested-student-activities">Suggested Student Activities<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#suggested-student-activities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

What should you do if you see another health care worker make a serious error?</td></tr><tr><td>5. <div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="medical-legal-puzzle">Medical Legal Puzzle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-legal-puzzle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20260113-63885159.jpeg" alt="img-31.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="across">Across<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#across" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol start="2">
<li>When false statements damage a person's reputation.</li>
<li>For example, a physical therapist treats a child without parental consent.</li>
<li>For example, when a dentist writes a letter to a newspaper editor claiming that a patient is a big baby and never pays his bills.</li>
<li>False _____ can be charged if a patient is restrained without proper authorisation.</li>
<li>A wrongful act that does not involve a contract.</li>
<li>Informed _______ is permission granted voluntarily by a person who is of sound mind.</li>
<li>Malpractice is often described as bad _____ or professional negligence.</li>
<li>An example of abuse when a health care worker swears and shouts at a patient.</li>
<li>For example, when a nurse tells the press something about a celebrity patient that is insulting and untrue.</li>
</ol>
<p>202</p>
<p>203</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="down">Down<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#down" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Any care resulting in physical harm, pain, or mental anguish.</li>
<li>Unnecessarily exposing an individual.</li>
<li>For example, a doctor cuts into the bladder when removing the uterus.</li>
<li>A threat or attempt to injure.</li>
<li>For example, nursing assistant used hot bath water and burned patient.</li>
<li>Invasion of privacy can be caused by revealing ______ information about a patient.</li>
<li>Type of informed consent required for major surgery.</li>
<li>Negligence occurs when care that is ______ expected is not given.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="legal-and-ethical-questions">Legal and Ethical Questions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#legal-and-ethical-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>What is a threat or attempt to injure? Assault</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If a nurse assistant forgets to raise the side rails on the bed and the patient falls out of bed, the nurse assistant might be guilty of: Negligence.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If a physician fails to use the degree of skill and learning commonly expected in that individuals profession, the physician could be guilty of: Malpractice.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A person who is under the influence of drugs does not have the legal capacity to form a contract because he/she has a: Legal disability.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If a laboratory technician sends e-mails to co-workers saying that a particular physician is careless and killed a patient, the lab tech might be guilty of: Libel.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>What term describes the fact that information about a patient must remain private? Confidentiality</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Before you perform any procedure on a patient, you must have proper: Authorisation.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>What should you do as a health care worker do if you make a mistake? Report it immediately to your supervisor.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When can a health care worker accept a tip or bribe? Never</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>What term describes a standard code of conduct for health professionals? Ethics or Code of Ethics</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A nurse is helping a patient walk and jerks the patient by the arm, causing a bruise. The nurse may be guilty of: Battery.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>What is permission granted voluntarily by a person who is of sound mind after the procedure has been explained in terms the person can understand? Informed consent.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If a health care worker makes false statements about a patient that cause the patient to be damaged or ridiculed, the health care worker may be guilty of: Defamation (or slander).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Speaking harshly, swearing or shouting, and using inappropriate words to describe a persons tribe or nationality are all examples of what kind of abuse? Verbal.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>What kind of contract exists when a nurse is holding a thermometer and says put this under your tongue and the patient puts the thermometer under his or her tongue? Implied contract.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>If I have the legal capacity to sign a consent form, I must be: 18-years-old and mentally competent. (Free of legal disability).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>What patients rights document applies to persons in long-term care facilities? Residents Bill of Rights.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>A document that a person signs to indicate he/she does not want to be resuscitated when he/she stops breathing is a: Living will.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Health care records are examples of: Privileged communications</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>What is an example of physical abuse? Hitting, forcing people against their will, etc.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Keeping someone in the hospital against their will could be an example of: Forced imprisonment.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Janes father signs a document saying that Jane will make decisions for him once he is unable to make decisions. The document is a: Durable Power of Attorney.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>According to professional standards, before a health care worker performs any procedure on a patient, the health care worker should: Identify the patient and/or obtain the patients consent.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="52e21b3e">Patients Rights and Duties<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#52e21b3e" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th></th><th>Circle the correct answer</th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1</td><td>Patients have the right to know whether medical treatment is experimental.</td><td>True</td><td>False</td></tr><tr><td>2</td><td>Patients have the right to smoke in the hospital</td><td>True</td><td>False</td></tr></tbody></table>

Or have the duty to follow physician orders</td><td>True</td><td>False</td></tr><tr><td>6</td><td>All patients have the right to confidentiality</td><td>True</td><td>False</td></tr><tr><td>7</td><td>Patients may examine their bills, but cannot expect to have them explained due to the many extraneous charges that are accrued</td><td>True</td><td>False</td></tr><tr><td>8</td><td>Patients have a duty to be considerate and respectful to health providers?</td><td>True</td><td>False</td></tr><tr><td>9</td><td>Patients who are hospitalized cannot expect consideration of privacy due to the intimate nature of many exams and procedures</td><td>True</td><td>False</td></tr></tbody></table>

<p>Transparency International-Kenya (2011) Kenya Health Sector Integrity Study Report. Nairobi: Transparency International-Kenya.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="purpose">Purpose<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#purpose" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>To enable students to understand the processes and management of health information systems</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="objectives">Objectives<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#objectives" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>By the end of this module, the student should be able to:</p>
<ol>
<li>Define health information systems and identify key components;</li>
<li>Explain the structure of the health information system in Kenya;</li>
<li>Identify the sources of health information.</li>
</ol>
