<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="14-1-definition-of-a-health-system">14.1 Definition of a Health System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#14-1-definition-of-a-health-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A system is an arrangement of parts which are connected together for a purpose. A health system is concerned with peoples health. A health system has many parts that include patients, families and communities, Ministry of Health, health providers, health services organisations, pharmaceutical companies, professional societies and health financing bodies, and other organisations. The interconnections of the health system can be viewed as the functions and roles played by these parts.</p>
<p>The World Health Organisation (WHO) defines health systems as all organisations, institutions, and resources that are devoted to producing health actions. This definition includes the full range of players engaged in the provision and financing of health services including the public, private sector, NGO, FBO as well as international and bilateral donors, foundations, and voluntary organisations involved in funding or implementing health activities.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="14-2-health-system-governance">14.2 Health System Governance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#14-2-health-system-governance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Governance in health refers the actions and means adopted by a country to organise, promote and protect the health of its population. The governance framework and its functioning can be formal e.g. Public Health Act, International Health Regulations or informal e.g. Hippocratic Oath to prescribe and proscribe behaviour. The health governance framework in Kenya is a</p>
<p>devolved system. Good governance is also closely linked with effective leadership and efficient management which are covered in Module One.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="objective">Objective<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#objective" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The objective of health governance is to promote and protect the health of a population at the individual, community, county and national level. An effective health governance system is therefore one which competently directs health system resources, performance, and stakeholder participation toward the goal of reducing illness, saving lives and doing so in ways that are open, transparent, accountable, equitable, and responsive to the needs of the people.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="characteristics-of-an-effective-health-system">Characteristics of an Effective Health System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#characteristics-of-an-effective-health-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>i. Well defined rules, roles and responsibilities of each of the actors in the health system and the relationships, structures, and procedures that connect them;</p>
<p>ii. Accountable to citizens, health service users, stakeholders and the wider community within which health care providers work, take decisions and lead their people to achieve their objectives;</p>
<p>iii. An enabling environment through which policy makers, county health management teams and hospital management teams and other sectors and actors are able to direct, monitor and supervise the conduct and operation of the health system and its management in a manner that ensures appropriate levels of authority, accountability, stewardship, leadership, direction and control;</p>
<p>iv. A responsible leadership which portrays, efficiency, probity, transparency and accountability.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="14-3-policy-framework">14.3 Policy Framework<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#14-3-policy-framework" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The Kenya health sector operates in the context of a number of policy frameworks and within a policy environment that is subject to both internal and external influences. The MDGs, and other global initiatives, and Vision 2030 Sector Plan for Health comprise the major external influences on the Kenyan health sector system. The health sector strategic plan and the community health strategy are some of the factors within the institutional and organisational context which shape the internal environment.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-in-the-millennium-development-goals">Health in the Millennium Development Goals<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-in-the-millennium-development-goals" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The MDGs provide a common set of priorities for addressing poverty. Health is represented in three of the eight goals as shown on Table 14.1</p>
<p>234</p>
<p>Table 14.1 Health Related Millennium Development Goals</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Goal</th><th>Health Indicator</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Goal 4: Reduce child mortality</td><td> Under-five mortality rate</td></tr><tr><td>Target: Reduce by two-thirds, between 1990 and 2015, the under-five mortality rate</td><td> Infant mortality rate</td></tr><tr><td> Proportion of one-year-old children immunised against measles</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Goal 5: Improve maternal health</td><td> Maternal mortality ratio</td></tr><tr><td>Target: Reduce by three-quarters, between 1990 and 2015, the maternal mortality ratio</td><td> Proportion of births attended by skilled health personnel experience at each level</td></tr><tr><td>Goal 6: Combat HIV/AIDS, malaria and other diseases</td><td> HIV prevalence among pregnant women aged 15-24 years</td></tr><tr><td>Target: Have halted by 2015 and begun to reverse the spread of HIV/AIDS</td><td> Condom use rate of the contraceptive prevalence rate</td></tr><tr><td> Ratio of school attendance of orphans to school attendance of non-orphans aged 10-14 years</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Have halted by 2015 and begun to reverse the incidence of malaria and other major diseases</td><td> Prevalence and death rates associated with malaria</td></tr><tr><td> Proportion of population in malaria-risk areas using effective malaria prevention and treatment measures</td><td></td></tr><tr><td> Prevalence and death rates associated with tuberculosis</td><td></td></tr><tr><td> Proportion of tuberculosis cases detected and cured under DOTS (Directly Observed Treatment Short-course)</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Implications of MDGs on health systems governance</p>
<p>From a health perspective, the MDGs are important because:</p>
<p>i. They provide a common set of priorities for addressing poverty;
ii. Health is at the heart of the MDGs. This recognition signifies that health is central to the global agenda of reducing poverty as well as an important measure of human well-being;
iii. They set quantifiable and ambitious targets against which to measure progress. These provide an indication of whether efforts are on track, and a means of holding decision-makers to account;
iv. It is possible to calculate what it would cost to achieve the MDGs. This draws attention to the funding gap between available and needed resources, thus providing support to health sector calls for increased funding;</p>
<p>v. MDGs have helped to crystallise the challenges in health. If a country looks seriously at what it would take to achieve the health MDGs, the bottlenecks to progress become clearer.</p>
<p>The challenges to health brought out in the MDGs are the need to strengthen health systems, ensure that health is prioritised within overall development and economic policies develop health strategies that respond to the diverse and evolving needs of the population, mobilise more resources for health at the national and county level, and improve the quality of health data.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="student-activity">Student activity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#student-activity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>MDGs provide an overarching framework for development efforts, and benchmarks against which to judge success.</p>
<ol>
<li>Identify and discuss the health elements in MDGs 1,2,3,7 and 8</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-sector-and-the-vision-2030">Health sector and the Vision 2030<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-sector-and-the-vision-2030" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The aim of the Kenya Vision 2030 is to create a globally competitive and prosperous country with a high quality of life by 2030 through transforming the country from a third world country into an industrialised, middle income country. To improve the overall livelihoods of Kenyans, Vision 2030 provides aspirations and direction on the provision of efficient, integrated and high quality affordable health care. The health sector reform strategy lays particular emphasis on: geographical and financial access to health care services; regional and gender disparities; efficiency; financing; health care policy; and public private partnerships.</p>
<p>236</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="14-4-the-legal-framework-of-the-health-sector">14.4 The Legal Framework of the Health Sector<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#14-4-the-legal-framework-of-the-health-sector" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The legal framework of the health sector in Kenya is governed primarily by Kenya's Health Policy Framework (KHPF) of 1994. The document in its agenda for reform, identified the strengthening of the central public policy role of the Ministry of Health in all matters pertaining to health as a key priority. In terms of regulation and enforcement, the government has over the years asserted its commitment to continue regulating the health sector by enforcing the following Acts of Parliament pertaining to the health sector:</p>
<p>i. Public Health Act cap 242.
ii. Radiation Protection Act cap 243.
iii. Pharmacy and Poisons Act cap 244.
iv. Dangerous Drugs Act cap 245.
v. Malaria Prevention Act cap 246.
vi. Mental Health Act cap 248.
vii. Medical Practitioners and Dentist Act cap 253.
viii. Nurses Act cap 257.
ix. Clinical Officers (Training, Registration and Licensing) Act cap 260.
x. National Hospital Insurance Fund Act cap 255.
xi. Food, Drugs and Chemical Substances Act cap 254.
xii. Animal Diseases Act cap 364.</p>
<p>The health sector is also impacted upon by other legislation. The following are some of the other statutes that impact on the health sector:</p>
<p>i. The Medical Laboratory Technicians and Technologist Act (1999).
ii. The Science and Technology Act cap 250.
iii. The Local Government Act cap 265.
iv. HIV and AIDS Prevention and Control Act, Act no 14 of 2006.
v. The Anatomy Act cap 249.
vi. The Public Procurement and Disposal Act 2005 Act no 3 of 2005 and the Regulations made therein.
vii. The Finance Act (enacted every financial year).
viii. Education Act cap 211.
ix. Kenya Medical Training College Act cap 261.
x. Various public universities acts.
xi. The Constitution of Kenya 2010 (especially Chapters creating the Public Service Commission and the County Public Service Commission.</p>
<p>239</p>
<p>xii. The Penal Code (1960).</p>
<p>xiii. The Sexual Offences Act 2006.</p>
<p>All these statutes have an impact on the health sector. For instance, the Finance Act directly affects the budgetary allocation to the Ministry of Health. The Public Procurement and Disposal Act affects the manner in which the Ministry of Health acquires its supplies. The Education Act and various legislation governing public universities affect the quality of training given to health workers in those institutions. The Public Service Commission Act affects the Ministry of Healths organisational structure, appointments, promotions and staff discipline. The Penal Code provides for criminal liability for health workers who facilitate abortions. The National Commission on Gender and Development is mandated to promote gender equity in health. The Public Health Act, section 3(1) establishes a Central Board of Health whose function is to advise the minister on all matters affecting public health. The Constitution of Kenya 2010 provides for equality and freedom from discrimination (Art 27) and the right to health and reproductive health (Art 43).</p>
<p>In the current legal framework, there are over twenty statutes dealing with the health sector in the country. The legal framework of the health sector is not under a single institution but spread within a number of ministries and departments of the government. Within the Ministry of Health, there are divisions, departments and specialised agencies responsible for different aspects of health regulations. In the devolved system of governance, this scenario is replicated at the county level.</p>
<p>The health sector policy focus is guided by Vision 2030. The strategic focus is well defined and elaborated in the Kenya Health Policy with clear goals on the long-term policy directions the country intends to achieve in pursuit of the imperatives of the Vision 2030, and the 2010 Constitution.</p>
<p>Governance of the health sector is anchored on current key policy, legal and legislative frameworks. The Kenya Health policy 2012-2030, Health Act 2012 and Kenya Health Sector Strategic and Investment Plan 2012-2017 are the key instruments which align the sector with the Constitution of Kenya 2010 and the social pillar of Vision 2030. These and other policy documents guide the two levels of Governments (National and County) and the health sector as a whole.</p>
<p><strong>Vision:</strong> A healthy and globally competitive nation</p>
<p><strong>Mission</strong> To deliberately build progressive, responsive and sustainable technologically-driven, evidence-based and client-centred health system for accelerated attainment of highest standard of health to all Kenyans</p>
<p><strong>Goal</strong> Better health in a responsive manner</p>
<p>240</p>
<p>To fulfil the vision and mission of the health Sector, those with management and leadership responsibilities are expected to formulate health policies and strategic direction, set standards and ensure provision of health services through public facilities and regulation of all actors/services.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="health-policy-objectives">Health Policy Objectives<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-policy-objectives" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The following six policy objectives provide guidance towards the realisation of the health sector vision and goal.</p>
<p>Table 14.3 Kenya Health Policy Objectives and Activities</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Objective</th><th>Activity</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Eliminate communicable conditions</td><td>Reduction of the burden of communicable diseases, till they are not of major public health concern.</td></tr><tr><td>Halt and reverse the rising burden of non-communicable conditions</td><td>Ensuring clear strategies for implementation to address all the identified non communicable conditions in the country.</td></tr><tr><td>Reduce the burden of violence and injuries</td><td>Collaboration with stakeholders in other sectors that address each of the causes of injuries and violence at the time.</td></tr><tr><td>Provide essential health care</td><td>Provision of medical services that are affordable, equitable, accessible and responsive to client needs.</td></tr><tr><td>Minimise exposure to health risk factors</td><td>Strengthening health promoting interventions, which address risk factors to health, plus facilitating use of products and services that lead to healthy behaviour in the population.</td></tr><tr><td>Strengthen collaboration with other sectors</td><td>Building partnerships and other integrative approaches which ensures the health sector interacts with and influences design implementation and monitoring processes in all health related sector actions.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="international-commitments-and-obligations">International Commitments and Obligations<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#international-commitments-and-obligations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The country has ratified many global commitments meant to support the health sector implement the various global commitments it has entered signed. These include:</p>
<p>i. Implementation of the International Health Regulations  to guide the country on key actions needed to assure adherence to international health regulations;
ii. Implementation of the Global Framework Convention for Tobacco Control  to guide the country on tobacco control activities;
iii. Ouagadougou declaration on Primary Health Care and Health Systems  to guide the overall strategic focus for the health sector;</p>
<p>iv. Millennium Development Declaration (MDGs)  to guide the country in developing national targets towards international development initiatives;
v. International Health Partnerships (IHP+) on Aid Effectiveness;
vi. UN Secretary Generals Global Strategy Every woman, every child;
vii. Abuja Declaration  to support the improvements of health systems in the country by domesticating the provisions through national legislation, the country committed in the Abuja Declaration to allocate 15% of government expenditure budget to health;
viii. International Human Right agreements including International Declaration for Human Rights, Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women (CEDAW), Child Rights Convention (CRC), the International Conference on Population and Development programme of action (ICPD), and the Beijing Declaration and Platform of Action (BPFA).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="14-5-governance-responsibilities-in-the-health-system">14.5 Governance Responsibilities in the Health System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#14-5-governance-responsibilities-in-the-health-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Various forms of governance functions and responsibilities exist at each level of the health system structures discussed in Module 1.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="objectives-of-governance-management-structure">Objectives of Governance/Management Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#objectives-of-governance-management-structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>Delivery of efficient, cost effective and equitable health services</li>
<li>Devolution of health service delivery, administration and management to community level</li>
<li>Stakeholder participation and accountability in health service delivery, administration and management</li>
<li>Operational autonomy</li>
<li>Efficient and cost-effective monitoring, evaluation, reviewing and reporting system</li>
<li>Smooth transition from current to proposed devolved arrangement</li>
<li>Complementarity of efforts and interventions</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-role-of-the-state-department-responsible-for-health">The Role of the State Department Responsible for Health<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-role-of-the-state-department-responsible-for-health" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The primary role of the National Department of Health is to support counties in delivering health care services as well as to help to lead, shape and support the national health care system. The KHSSP 2013-2017 outlines the mandate, structure, roles and responsibilities of the state department responsible for health as discussed below.</p>
<p>The principal mandate of the National State Department as stipulated in the Constitution of Kenya 2010 and National Health Policy 2012-2030 is:</p>
<p>i. Establishing a national health policy and legislation, standard setting, national reporting;</p>
<p>ii. Sector coordination and resource mobilisation;
iii. Offering technical support with emphasis on planning, development and monitoring of Health services and delivery standards throughout the country;
iv. Monitoring quality and standards of performance of the county governments in the provision of health services;
v. Providing national health referral services;
vi. Conducting studies required for administrative or management purposes.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="semi-autonomous-government-agencies-sagas">Semi-Autonomous Government Agencies (SAGAs)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#semi-autonomous-government-agencies-sagas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There are six SAGAs under the state department responsible for health. SAGAs are governed by a board of management (BoM) comprising 8-15 senior officer members representing the public sector (state department responsible for health and other ministries), and private sector and other stakeholders. A chief executive officer (CEO) is responsible for the daily management and implementation of the institutions' strategic plans which are guided by the sector strategic plan. Each SAGA operates under a performance contract signed with the Principal Secretary in the state department responsible for health. They are partly financed through GOK (state department of finance).</p>
<p>Table 14.6 SAGAs and their Key Mandates</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>SAGA</th><th>Founded</th><th>Corporation status date</th><th>Key Mandate</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Kenyatta national Hospital (KNH)</td><td>1901</td><td>Legal notice no.109 (April 1987)</td><td>Provide specialized care, training and research</td></tr><tr><td>Moi Teaching and Referral Hospital (MTRH)</td><td>1917</td><td>Legal notice no.78 (June 1998)</td><td>Provide specialized care, training and research</td></tr><tr><td>Kenya Medical Training College (KMTC)</td><td>1927</td><td>Legal notice no.14 (1994)</td><td>Train middle level health professionals</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>1990</td><td>KMTC Act cap 61</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Kenya Medical Research Institute (KEMRI)</td><td>1979</td><td>Science and technology act no.79 (April 1979)</td><td>Conduct multi-sector health research</td></tr><tr><td>Kenya Medical Supplies Agency (KEMSA)</td><td>2001</td><td>Act of Parliament cap 446 (2000), Legal notice no.17</td><td>Procure, warehouse and distribute health commodities in Kenya</td></tr><tr><td>National Hospital Insurance fund (NHIF)</td><td>1966</td><td>Act 9 (1998)</td><td>Provide quality social health insurance</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-role-and-structure-of-the-county-department-for-health">The Role and Structure of the County Department for Health<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-role-and-structure-of-the-county-department-for-health" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="county-health-management-structure">County Health Management Structure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#county-health-management-structure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>According to the Constitution of Kenya 2010, county governments are responsible for:</p>
<p>i. County health facilities and pharmacies;
ii. Ambulance services;
iii. Promotion of primary health care;</p>
<p>iv. Licensing and control of undertakings that sell food to the public;
v. Veterinary services excluding regulation of the profession;
vi. Cemeteries, funeral parlours and crematoria; and
vii. Refuse removal, refuse dumps and solid waste disposal.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="structure-of-county-department-responsible-for-health">Structure of County Department Responsible for Health<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#structure-of-county-department-responsible-for-health" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>County health services are managed by a Chief Officer for Health who reports to the County Executive Committee (CEC) member responsible for health.</p>
<p>Table 14.5 Structure for County Department Responsible for Health
<img src="assets/images/image-20260113-9daa41c9.jpeg" alt="img-39.jpeg">
Source: Adapted from Kenya Health Sector Strategic and Investment Plan  KHSSP July 2012-June 2017.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="governance-responsibilities-at-the-county-level">Governance Responsibilities at the County Level<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#governance-responsibilities-at-the-county-level" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="chief-officer-for-health">Chief Officer for Health<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chief-officer-for-health" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The Chief Officer for Health is responsible for technical coordination and management of County Health Services, focusing on:</p>
<p>247</p>
<p>i. Overall management and oversight of public health facilities in the county;
ii. Guiding implementation of health related issues from the county executive committee;
iii. Interpreting, and integrating national government health policy;
iv. Coordinating development and implementation of county health strategies and priorities;
v. Coordinating disaster preparedness and response in the county;
vi. Management of referral health services, in county, across counties, and with the national government;
vii. Act as the accounting officer of the department responsible for health.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="county-director-of-health">County Director of Health<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#county-director-of-health" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The County Director of health is the technical advisor for all health matters in the county. Their role shall be:</p>
<p>i. The technical advisor to the County Executive Commissioner and the Governor;
ii. To supervise all health services within the County;
iii. To promote the public health and the prevention, limitation or suppression of infectious, communicable or preventable diseases within the County;
iv. To prepare and publish reports and statistical or other information relative to the public health within the County;
v. To report periodically to the Chief Officer for health on all public health occurrences including disease outbreaks, disasters and any other health matters;
vi. To perform any other duties as may be assigned by the appointing authority and any other written law.</p>
<p>The County Director of health is the technical advisor for all health matters in the county. Their role shall be:</p>
<p>i. The technical advisor to the County Executive Commissioner and the Governor;
ii. To supervise all health services within the County;
iii. To promote the public health and the prevention, limitation or suppression of infectious, communicable or preventable diseases within the County;</p>
<p>248</p>
<p>iv. To prepare and publish reports and statistical or other information relative to the public health within the County;
v. To report periodically to the Director-General for health on all public health occurrences including disease outbreaks, disasters and any other health matters;
vi. To perform any other duties as may be assigned by the appointing authority and any other written law.</p>
<p>Table 14.8 Other Structural Units at the County Level</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Units</th><th>Policy implementation responsibilities</th><th>Constitutional functions</th><th>Constituent Sub-units</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Preventive and Promotive Services</td><td>- Eliminate Communicable Conditions - Minimize exposure to health risk factors</td><td>- Promotion of primary health care - License &amp;control undertakings that sell food to the public - Refuse removal; refuse dumps and solid waste disposal</td><td>- Child Health - HIV, TB and Malaria - Health Promotion - Neglected Disease management - Hygiene control - Community services</td></tr><tr><td>Clinical Services</td><td>- Halt and reverse the rising burden of Non Communicable Conditions - Provision of essential health services - Reducing the burden of violence and injuries</td><td>- Ambulance services - Management of health facilities and pharmacies - Cemeteries; funeral parlors and crematoria</td><td>- Maternal Health - Blood Safety - Laboratory services - Pharmaceutical services - Nursing services</td></tr><tr><td>Planning and Monitoring</td><td>- Organization &amp;management of health service delivery Strengthening collaboration with health related sectors</td><td></td><td>- Health Planning - Sector Coordination - Health Information</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Source: Adapted from Kenya Health Sector Strategic and Investment Plan  KHSSP July 2012-June 2017.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="stewardship-responsibilities-at-the-different-levels-of-the-health-sector">Stewardship Responsibilities at the Different Levels of the Health Sector<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stewardship-responsibilities-at-the-different-levels-of-the-health-sector" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The Constitution reserves the responsibility for health policy to the national government. The state department of health is responsible for shaping policy direction for health in the country, and for facilitating the implementation of a sector-wide approach. The principal mandate of the state department of health is as stipulated in the Constitution and the Health Policy and is further detailed in the table below.</p>
<p>Table 14.9 Stewardship Responsibilities at the Different Levels of the Health Sector</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>National Government Policy Role</th><th>Corresponding County Government Role</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1)</td><td>Establishing a National Health Policy and Legislation, health regulation and standard setting, national reporting, sector coordination &amp;resource mobilization</td><td>County level prioritization of health investments, setting and reporting on relevant targets; and coordination of actors in the county health system</td></tr><tr><td>2)</td><td>Offering technical support with emphasis on planning, development and monitoring of Health services and delivery standards throughout the country</td><td>Planning, development and monitoring of County Health Services; and facilitating compliance with national health standards</td></tr><tr><td>3)</td><td>Monitor quality and standards of performance of the County Governments and community organizations in the provision of Health services</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>4)</td><td>Provide guidelines on tariffs chargeable for the provisions of Health services; and the distribution of health benefits through various financing mechanisms</td><td>Provide guidance to health facilities within the county in implementing health service tariffs and benefits</td></tr><tr><td>5)</td><td>Provide National health referral services</td><td>Development and management of referral services within the county health system</td></tr><tr><td>6)</td><td>Conduct national studies required for administrative or management purposes</td><td>Conduct county studies required for administrative or management purposes</td></tr><tr><td>7)</td><td>Develop national guidelines on the role of non-state actors in health; and regulate their services</td><td>Facilitate the role of non-state actors in the county health system; and ensure their compliance with national policy and regulatory requirements</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Source: Adapted from Kenya Health Sector Strategic and Investment Plan  KHSSP July 2012-June 2017.</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="stakeholder-involvement">Stakeholder Involvement<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stakeholder-involvement" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The right to health cannot be achieved without the active involvement of other stakeholders. Health sector stakeholders include:</p>
<p>Clients- The individuals, households, and communities whose health is the focus of this strategic plan;</p>
<p>State actors- The public sector (MoH  National and County, SAGAs, other ministries and the state department responsible for devolution), constitutional Commissions, regulatory bodies (boards and councils) and professional bodies/associations whose mandate is drawn from that of the state, and have an effect on health;</p>
<p>Non-state actors- The Private sector NGOs, Civil Society Organizations (CSOs), FBOs, traditional practitioners, media, and all other persons whose actions have an impact on health, but do not draw their mandate from the state;</p>
<p>External actors- The bilateral, multilateral, or philanthropic actors that draw their mandate from out of Kenya, but support national programmes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="health-sector-intergovernmental-relations-and-coordination-framework">Health Sector Intergovernmental Relations and Coordination Framework<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#health-sector-intergovernmental-relations-and-coordination-framework" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Effective governance is achieved through active engagement, consultation, cooperation and mutual accountability between the national department responsible for health and the county departments of health, as well engagement among the county departments of health. The Intergovernmental Relations Act 2012, Kenya Health Policy (2012-2030) and KHSSP 2013-2017 provide for a sound basis for intergovernmental relations framework in health.</p>
<p>The figure below presents an illustration of how the health sector partnership, governance, and stewardship processes work together to provide overall leadership in addressing the health agenda in the country.</p>

<li>Identify and discuss the role played by the various actors in the health system.</li>
<li>What ethical principles should guide governance practices in the health sector?</li>

<p>The Public Officer Ethics Act, 2003.</p>
<p>World Health Organisation (2009) Good Governance in Medicines: A Framework for Good Governance in the Pharmaceutical Sector: GGM Model Framework. Geneva: WHO.</p>
<p>254</p>
<p>255</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="purpose">Purpose<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#purpose" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>To introduce students to entrepreneurship in health services delivery</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="objectives">Objectives<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#objectives" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>By the end of this module, the student should be able to:</p>
<ol>
<li>Explain the basics of business management;</li>
<li>Develop a business.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="module-15-entrepreneurship-for-health-professionals">MODULE 15: ENTREPRENEURSHIP FOR HEALTH PROFESSIONALS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#module-15-entrepreneurship-for-health-professionals" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="content">Content<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#content" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="methodology">Methodology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#methodology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
